review_title: Not the worst movie, just dwindling for the franchise I guess
review_detailed_main: I didn't find it as horrible as all the reviews for it says. Maybe it's because I don't even remember the first Jaws which I saw as a kid and never saw any of the sequels. I didn't mind the idiosyncrasies of the shark following the family 1000s of kilometres faster than it can or the roar it makes which a shark could never make. All those make it dumb fun for me. The film tries to be emotional a bit and fails. But the cute kid made up a lot for it. The obsession of the characters was nicely portrayed but there was never any tension or drama to it. It was pretty light and whenever Michael Cain came on screen he made it feel like this is a slice-of-life feel-good movie. Overall it is a very mixed bag with nothing particularly strong but it was an easy breezy watch that kept my interest. If I'd have actually saw the three movies before this, maybe I would have been bored by this.

Watched for the "How Did This Get Made" Podcast, I've seen "Jaws: The Revenge" before, or rather, I must have done, but I remembered almost nothing about it. It has a reputation as one of the legendarily bad films, though when you watch a lot of the films covered by this podcast, you can see that whilst it's not good, it's nowhere near the worst cinematic experiences out there.

After losing her youngest son, Sean (Mitchell Anderson) to a Great White Shark attack, Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary) travels to the Bahamas with her eldest Michael (Lance Guest) and his family. Ellen is convinced that this shark is targeting her family, which meets incredulity from anyone she tells about it. However, the same shark then arrives in the Bahamas, which is very unusual given the temperature of the water there. Michael is a marine biologist and, despite his own family history with Sharks, is convinced by his partner Jake (Mario Van Peebles) to study the unusual arrival.

Again, after watching so many awful films for this podcast I might be grading on a different scale to most people and again, within that, "Jaws: The Revenge" is not good. It's got some extraordinary plot holes that it just ignores and that's before we come to the idea that a shark can have a vendetta against a family, let alone set traps to encourage them into the water. The performances, particularly from Gary are ... questionable and, as was often the case when he wasn't that bothered, Michael Caine plays himself.

The shark is generally a ropey effect, where you can see the unnaturalness of the movement, as week as occasionally the wires moving the puppet. That said, on the couple of occasions when a full human actor ends up in its mouth, those scenes look quite good.

It is a bad film, don't get me wrong, but I've seen a hundred worse ones.

The previous two Jaws movie sequels are not as good as the first, because Jaws (1975) is a classic from director Steven Spielberg with John Williams composing the music, so it is hard to beat it with a sequel/follow-up; the second movie was not as good and the third movie was worse than the second, and the fourth movie is no different. The fourth movie Jaws: The Revenge (1987) is as bad as the third movie but where the third movie was entertaining and more of the shark, this movie takes a while to get to the shark with it taking its time with its slow pacing; the performances were off, the dialogue was not that good, the editing in attack scenes was very bad, and the characters will act weird in the weird situations for no reason.

Since the character Brody is not in the movie with a poor reason, and since this is a continuation in a way of the first two, we follow Brody's wife Ellen Brody once again played by Lorraine Gary; though I understand why she would not want her family to go near the water, I still think it is stupid to think the shark followed her away from Amity Island to somewhere in the Bahamas and specifically targeting her and her family. The characters tend to do dumb things or a character, mostly the two family members in Ellen Brody's family, have a job of some kind that has them going on the water that will lead to them getting killed off in a hard to see bloody way or luckily survive somehow. All I can say about the characters is that they are not likable, they can change their emotions or opinions on something in seconds for no reason, so you question it, and they act weird at random moments like acting sad in a happy moment and acting happy in a sad moment.

The shark is once again an animatronic, which is still impressive, but whenever the shark is shown clearly swimming around or jumping out and attacking people, it looks silly, and you laugh when you should not; speaking of the shark attacking people, the attack scenes are edited and cut badly with it being hard to tell what is happening to a character and if they survived or not, all you can see is splashing of water and some blood effects until they are gone. The music is not as good as the music done by composer John Williams, and the use the same good Jaws theme that is used in all the movies; there is not much else to say about this movie except that it is a stupid unintentionally funny bad movie that has bad pacing for a short movie with it taking a while to get to the shark.

Jaws: The Revenge (1987) is as bad as Jaws 3-D (1983), but this movie was a bit slow, where the third movie went from dumb scenes to dumb scene to make the movie entertaining, even though it was not good; this movie does not have likable characters you care for, bad editing, bad use of effects, bad dialogue, and lots of unintentionally funny moments. I would highly recommend watching the original Jaws (1975) directed by Steven Spielberg if you have not already, and if you have, just go and rewatch it; you can at least watch Jaws 2 (1978), but do not bother the third and fourth movie if you are that much of a fan of the original.

review_title: A movie sequel with real bite!
review_detailed_main:
Why is it that co-called 'movie critics' always seem to hate sequels? I bet half the time they don't even bother to watch the movie themselves. If anyone had actually bothered to to watch Jaws 4 they'd soon realise that it's a great movie. Forget the first three movies in the series (I can't remember what they were called, but don't bother looking them up - it ain't worth it) this is the one to watch. It's got a great cast, a great script and a great villain.

Some people complain about the low body-count in this movie. Well, I say if you want a high body-count go and hire out some 'dumb-a**' action movie like 'Cross of Iron'. Plenty of people die in that movie. What you get with Jaws 4 is a serious attempt to get inside the mind of Great White Shark. As it says on the movie's tag line "This time... it's personal". And it certainly is as the shark seeks to avenge the deaths of the other sharks in the previous movies by swimming off to the Bahamas in an attempt to eat Lorraine Gary (she's the wife of the guy in the first two movies). And who can blame it? Sharks always seem to be cast as bad guys in the movies (just look at all those James Bond movies - the bad guy always seems to keep killer sharks as pets). People seem to forget that the sharks were there first, no wonder they get a bit annoyed when idiots in boats keep chasing them, and anyhow they're only trying to get something to eat. How would you like it every time you went into Burger King for a Big Whopper you got some guy chasing you with a harpoon gun?

Also, some people complain that the shark isn't very realistic, that its rubber teeth can sometimes be seen bending - well you'd hardly expect them to use a real shark!

It's also great to see a major Hollywood movie with a 'mature' woman leading the cast, not some 20 year old bimbo with silicon implants. Maybe that's what a lot of the critics didn't like - a strong, intelligent middle-aged woman.

review_title: OK, OK, let's get down to business....
review_detailed_main:
Jaws "3-D" was not good. This on the other hand, is average. I find it funny how Hollywood doesn't see what an over amount of sequels do. They keep trying to take chances, but it just doesn't work out. I mean look at the original Jaws! Just take a look! An instant classic. Back then, it was a terrifying, gruesome, and great horror flick! It changed peoples minds about going into the water! And now, it all comes down to this! Look at were this got us! They're lucky that they didn't ruin Jaws because OF 3 and 4! Having said that, this motion picture is better then 3. That's my opinion. It's actually the most gory/intense also. Hence the "PG-13" rating! But it's just not.... "It"! Not Jaws! Not original! Average at best. End of story.

6/10

PG-13-For Intense Shark Attack Sequences, And Language.

I gave this 5 because I thought it was directed really nicely. I was actually quite impressed. It's a crazy concept and you wouldn't want to bother focusing your whole attention on it but I had it on in the background while doing other things and thought it was OK.

In Amity Island, Sean Brody (Mitchell Anderson) is the Chief of Police and soon will marry Tiffany (Mary Smith). One night, Sean is summoned to remove a wood pillar from a buoy and is murdered by a great white shark. His mother, Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary), believes that the shark is seeking revenge against her family since her husband and son have been killed by a white shark. Michael Brody (Lance Guest), who is presently married with the artist Carla Brody (Karen Young) and with a daughter, Thea (Judith Barsi), and living in Bahamas, invites his mother to stay with his family. They fly home with the pilot Hoagie (Michael Caine), where Michael is researching snails to complete his PhD with his friend Jake (Mario Van Peebles). Ellen is still obsessed with the white shark, and when Michael and Jake find that there is one in the area, they use a GPS device to track it. Further, they hide the information from their wives and Ellen. Until the day that the shark attacks a beach where Thea is on a banana boat ride.

"Jaws: The Revenge" is the worst movie from the franchise, with the stupid premise of a great white shark seeking revenge to the Brody family like an Italian mobster. The cast of "Jaws 3D" does not participate of this turkey, and is weird to see different actors performing Michael and Sean Brody. The most surprising is the name of the great actor Michael Caine in the cast. The ridiculous Ellen Brody destroys the vessel of her son and the plane of her boyfriend to do what? "Jaws: The Revenge" is probably the source of inspiration of "Sharknado" franchise. My vote is three.

Title (Brazil): "Tubarão 4: A Vingança" ("Shark 4: The Revenge")

A truly lame sequel to the excellent original. The ADR is awful in the movie and so obvious right from the start. The premise of the movie is absurd and it's execution is badly done too. Our main character comes off as a hysterical Killjoy it's just not believeable that Michael Caine's character is meant to be in love, plus she has all these mad visions and so on too. The film is only 90 minutes long, there's barely a plot, hardly a body count, at times it turns into this boring family drama instead. The shark is ridiculous and seems to have developed the ability to walk on water now. There's no successful attempt to build suspense and some footage is even recycled from the original.

review_title: Fun if you don't take it seriously
review_detailed_main:
Despite all the negative reviews this film isn't all bad. Is it silly and implausible? Yes. Is it Shakespeare? No.

The shark looks faker than ever, but even in the original Jaws it looked dreadful. The series as a whole has always been silly to some extent.

People regularly mention the shark's impossible roar as though that is something unique to this film, but it was vocal in previous films too. Don't let it bother you.

Michael Small's reinterpretation of John Williams' Jaws theme and the soundtrack as whole are the highlight of the film and well worth seeking out of you're a fan of soundtracks.

In a world where a film like Sharknado not only exists but has five sequels this is positively a classic.

If you don't take it seriously then it's a fun way to pass a lazy Sunday afternoon.

review_title: This wasn't as bad as many made it out to be.
This movie is worse than any damage a shark can do
review_detailed_main:
Sequels were not usually good. However, Jaws: The Revenge is less than "not good." It is a disaster from one end to the other. Simply put: It's really, really bad!

Various things I have heard make this movie bad. First of all, a shark chooses Chief Brody, and somehow travels over 1000 miles in two days just to reach him. This would have built up suspense, if it weren't so unrealistic. Second, the shark only kills people in water. Smart move staying right next to a home surrounded by it, don't you think? Third, it somehow manages to get out of the water and bite off somebody's arm in the beginning. Fourth, the shark can't stay in the temperature of water it was in. It's cold-blooded, right? Fifth, was that there was a plot hole some where near the end. The sixth reason is that the shark came up to a dock or whatever, and started biting it, when the people were so far away.

But, I didn't notice many of these reason when I first watched it. The thing I hated the most about Jaws: The Revenge is how interesting it was, and it wasn't very interesting. If I could describe this film in one word, it would be: *yawn*.

If you see this, see it somewhere where you can easily walk away from.

Good: ...

Bad: Unrealistic, boring, plot holes, etc.

Feel free to send me a Private Message regarding this comment.

Ok, so it's not an oscar winner, but Jaws: The Revenge is still a great film. Lorraine Gary as Ellen Brody is what really makes the film. Her enormous talent is showcased in this movie. The shark moves a little too mechanical, but that is what makes the film more fun to watch. I enjoy this instalment of the Jaws series, more than all the others. The soundtrack is top notch, the cast is superb, the story is well written, and the action is high. I highly recommend this film.

review_title: For some strange reason, I enjoy it.
Your Jaws will drop on how bad this movie is!
review_detailed_main: Wow. This movie was awful. I would rather get eaten by Jaws then watch this movie again. What was Michael Caine doing in this crap-tastic movie? And for the love of god sharks DO NOT roar!!! They don't go after revenge on a human being! Even a person who has a IQ of -10000000000000000000000000000000 would know that! They tried to make us believe that sharks will go after revenge on you but please nobody is gonna believe that! No wounder why they stopped making Jaws movies after this! The tag line is stupid! Stupid characters with a ridiculous plot. Stupid and corny gave it a unrealistic feeling throughout. And I'm shocked that they didn't remake the first Jaws yet! I bet Spielberg is ashamed of this movie! The ending was pathetic. How could Mrs. Brody have flashbacks from when the shark died in the original and she wasn't even there!? It tried to hard to be the original Jaws. Should of been retitled as 'Jaws: The Crap'

review_title: Come on people it wasn't that bad!
So Dumb you will root for the shark
review_detailed_main:
The only thing better in this movie if the whiny kid Thea , would get eaten right away. Then eat the entire cast for general purpose.

The excrement that was produced should have been flushed at the onset. Of the producers pre meeting .
The best way to describe Jaws: The Revenge is absolutely unwatchable, poorly written, illogical, completely tensionless, ridiculous dream sequences and a menace to society.
One of the most awful movies I ever watched. Even for the '80, which was all about "trash". But this is just a joke. Rather go to sleep, than waste your time and watch this!
All the suspense is ruined by the fake looking shark and bad editing. The only good thing is the music from the original movie.

Perhaps the title refers to the revenge taken on anyone who said that the earlier Jaws sequels were bad. This is quite the most monumentally massive mistake in movie history. Even more so than Batman and Robin this film raises the question, 'which studio executive heard the pitch/script and said "hmmm, sounds promising. Here's a budget - go make me movie..."? Alan Smithee wouldn't put his name near this nonsense.

This film was made 12 years after the original but has positively the worst effects of all 4 films. The Jaws 3 model was bad enough but this thing is barely a shark. The fact that the shark has a gaping hole in it's belly means that the camera views are highly restricted and every time it jumps out of the water (which is nearly every appearance) it seems to pivot on its tail. During the banana boat scene it looks as if its floating on the surface it's so far out of the water.

For a 'scary' film, its death count is even worse than its predecessor (2 or 3 depending which ending is used). Basically everything about this film sucks. There's too much time wasted on land (there seems to be more emphasis on Ellen and Hogie's romance than on the shark), a ridiculous plot (Great White swimming to the Bahamas on personal vendetta) and, in the end, absolutely no feature worthy of anything other than ridicule.

Give a ten year-old a video camera, a rubber shark and some ketchup and you'd have a more effective film than this.

Maybe one day, a good script will be written and, with the aid of CG effects, the Jaws series will be put back on track. Perhaps the title 'Jaws 4' could be used just to wipe out all evidence of this.

Far and away the worst film I`ve ever seen.

This shark can fly, roar, chase aeroplanes and can infiltrate the mind of Chief Brody`s wife and yet is almost completely incapable of killing anyone.

The film uses about 20 minutes of footage from the first film. If that`s all they can do to make this interesting (just show the first one) it shows how crap this is.

There must be a million things wrong with this film. Far too many to list here anyway. Having said that, whenever this film is on TV I always watch it for a laugh.

I actually quite like this film, OK its not as good as 1 or 2 but its much better than 3D. There are lots of things people can pick faults with, The shark balancing on the water, but if you watch it as a film and put all the "it couldn't happen" out of your mind, you will see this film is quite good. People always say "Oh, that wouldn't happen in real life", thats because ITS A MOVIE! That is the whole point of films, to do things can you can't do in reality.

Anyway, back to the film, The fact that this film ignores the events of Jaws 3-D, is a bad idea but, the film survives well with what you are given. A shark related to one of the other sharks, attacking the remainders of the Broady family for revenge. Farfeched? OK maybe a little but overall this film, by reverting back to the originals formula, is very good. 9/10

Brody has been dead from a heart attack. The son deputy Sean Brody is killed by a shark on Amity Island. Other son Michael Brody (Lance Guest) and his family come home for the funeral. Mother Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary) is sure that the family is being hunted and she wants everybody away from the waters. They convince Ellen to come with them to their Bahamas home. Hoagie (Michael Caine) flies the plane to their island home. Jake (Mario Van Peebles) is their neighbor and fellow marine biologist.

The concept is laughable. Apparently a shark is hunting this family for revenge. In case you wonder if Michael Caine could salvage the material, the answer is no. He's said many times that he was doing it for the paycheck at this time. It looks like it. Almost nothing happens for a long stretch. The story is boring. It's filmed in a boring way. This is all very boring.
Just kidding - it's pretty terrible. Like the worst film you will ever see in your life.

review_title: Even the shark didn't have the stomach for this!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
review_detailed_main: You know a film franchise is in serious trouble if the box office returns are dwindling fast and the only actress left from the first movie is the studio bosses wife!!! Even Michael Caine hasn't seen this film and he starred in it!!! To quote the actor himself "I have never seen it, but by all accounts it is terrible. However, I have seen the house that it built, and it is terrific.".With a glowing recommendation like that this is a must see movie!!! NOT!!!! The plot is crap a shark out for revenge?I think not!A shark that explodes with the same recycled shot of it sinking after it collides with the bow of a boat after standing still on the water?Please give me a break!!!! This is one of the worst if not the worst sequel that I have ever seen in my life and I've seen a few.BAD BAD BAD. Even the shark is falling apart.Stay away from this one,oh thats right everybody did!!!!

review_title: One of the worst sequels ever...
review_detailed_main:
I didn't see Jaws:The Revenge until recently, after hearing so many bad things about it. And I do wish I left it alone, this has a reputation on the whole as being one of the worst sequels ever, and as far as I'm concerned that reputation is deserved. Steven Spielberg's Jaws is brilliant, not only one of his best films but also the very movie that made me afraid to go into the sea.

Jaws:The Revenge didn't have that effect on me whatsoever. In alternative to giving genuine scares and thrills, the whole film is laughable. Especially in the plot, which is really quite inept, and in the climax, which is the epitome of WTF? Jaws:The Revenge also has some embarrassingly cheesy dialogue and poor pacing. Then there's the direction, Spielberg's direction was one of the many things that made the 1975 film so good, but the direction here from Joseph Sargent is incompetent.

The production values don't fare much better. The locations are quite nice but the cinematography and lighting are altogether unexceptional. The music is also disappointing, whereas the music was what made Jaws so unnerving in terms of mood, it was way too gimmicky here. The less said about Bruce the shark the better, he is not menacing at all, instead he is one of the many laughable assets of the film. Also he is not used well at all, and there is little to no build-up or suspense whenever he appears on screen. The acting is atrocious, the only actor who tries and the only redeeming quality is Michael Caine who deserves better. Lorraine Grey is annoyingly neurotic, while I was shocked that the talented late Judith Barsi would participate in such a mess, and her talents aren't even put to good use. Don't get me started on Mario Van Peebles, him, his character and his comic lines are annoying and get old fast.

Overall, a terrible film and one of the worst sequels I've seen and I have seen a lot. 1/10 Bethany Cox

review_title: "Jaws: The Revenge" is the worst "shark movie" I've ever seen
review_detailed_main:
Let me just say that this film has to be one of the most terrible and embarrassing films I've ever seen in my entire life.

The first "Jaws" movie that Steven Spielberg directed back in 1975 was an absolute classic, one which didn't even need any sequels to it whatsoever.

Although "Jaws 2" was a surprisingly good sequel and "Jaws 3-D" was a fairly okay sequel, "Jaws: The Revenge", this is a movie that shouldn't even have been made if it was going to be this terrible.

Though the beginning of the movie starts out pretty good, it slowly begins to go downhill right from there. I can see now why this film was nominated for so many Razzie awards because it most certainly deserved it.

Let me begin shall I:









In conclusion,

This is one of the worst movies that I've ever seen in my entire life. Heck, on the back of the DVD case it says that it's a "suspense-packed thriller" and that it's "the scariest 'Jaws' of them all". Yeah? Well, that's complete bulls***! It is in no way, shape or form a suspense-packed thriller and it certainly isn't the scariest 'Jaws' movie of all time.

It's just like any other regular B-monster movie with poor actors, poor script and poor special effects. Only this one doesn't even show the shark most of the time, there's barely any action in this movie whatsoever, and not a lot of people get killed or eaten in it too. I've finished counting up exactly how many people actually get eaten by Jaws in this movie. The result is 2. How disappointing is that? That in the other "Jaws" films, more people got eaten by Jaws and in this one, the filmmakers made only 2 people get eaten by Jaws in a 1 hour and 31 minute film?

I don't even need to explain how terrifyingly bad this movie was any further. I think I've pretty much covered all of it up. If you're a fan of the first "Jaws" movie, I would recommend avoiding watching this poor excuse of a sequel. Trust me, it's totally not worth it.

With all of that said, I give "Jaws: The Revenge",

1 star out of 10.

"Jaws: The Revenge" can't compare, of course, with the first two entries, but even the suggestion that it's worse than "Jaws 3-D" is, in my opinion, preposterous: this is a definite improvement over the previous installment. I also can't understand the negative comments about the performances; they are all very good, at least for this undemanding genre. As for the "shark that travels faster than a plane", who said it's the same shark? Just because Ellen Brody believes that, doesn't mean it's the truth. This movie is passable. It leaves a bad aftertaste, though, because of its really dumb finale.
The plot of this movie is just laughable. A shark tracking down a family across America for revenge. I have no more words.

review_title: VERY GOOD if you use your SUSPENSION OF DISBELIEF

review_detailed_main: This film was alright for a 4th JAWS film. I like the way this film is shot in the Bahamas. The shark looks fake mostly due to the horrible editing of the mechanical parts being reviled more than once in this film. The acting is very well done by most of the actors. Music is some of the best since the first JAWS film. I liked it for what it is: a sappy 4th sequel to a classic thriller. I wish they had better editing and better plot writing in this film! Be sure to check out my other reviews for all the JAWS films Here is how it goes: JAWS: 10/10 JAWS II: 8/10 JAWS III (or JAWS 3-D): 4/10 and JAWS THE REVENGE (or JAWS IV) 7/10
Its not a "good" movie... but its not awful, it is an interesting movie, it kept my attention... true- its not as good as it could of been... but its watchable

review_title: Stupid and not that good but not god awful
review_detailed_main: Jaws 4 was definitely the worst of the series and was really really stupid but is OK if you do not think about it that much. This time the movies is that the new Jaws is hunting down members of the Brody family and after killing one of the sons the mother decides to move to her other sons house but never does she know the shark has followed her. The movie is pretty cool at bits and some characters are down pretty good but to be quite honest I only watched it because it has Michael Caine in it. Overall I think this movie is very, very stupid but does not deserve the extremely low rating that it has. So watch this if you just want to watch an OK horror movie that is pretty damn stupid so I rate it 52%.
I assure you that this is just a waste of your life

This is diabolically bad, plot full of holes, extremely irritating characters, bad casting, bad acting, idiotic character actions, etc.

2 stars for the rubber shark, the best actor in the movie!

Yes, Jaws the Revenge is cheesy and bad, BUT it is still somewhat watchable at 2 in the morning when you are bored and nothing else is on. I think Lorraine Gary is a great actress, actually. So is Lynn Whitfield. I do agree the little girl, Thea, is annoying, but what makes the film BAD, is the shark itself. I don't recall anything as fake looking as that pathetic thing they try to pass off as a shark in this film. I know they probably didn't have a big budget for this, but still, in all honesty, if the shark hadn't been so silly looking and do things that sharks don't do (roar, roll on side, stand on tail!, etc) then it would be more tolerable. At least the DVD is in widescreen...

review_title: Such a pain to sit through.

review_detailed_main: This is a stupid movie! Irrational, illogical, even more cheesy than Jaws 3-D, and cheap, useless special effects. This is probably the worst of all the Jaws films that never had clear reasoning to exist.

This film really did have potential. I mean, (most of) the Brody family is back, it's set back in Amity Island (instead of boring Sea World), and we get to see some familiar locations. Unfortunately, the potential flies out the window right when you pop this movie into your DVD player. The film score is great, but that's all there is to worship about the movie.

I may be wrong on this one, but wasn't Amity Island the Brody family's summer film? What the hell are they doing living in it in winter? Oh well, maybe since Martin's death, they couldn't pay for two homes. And speaking of Martin, I have to admit, the picture of him in the police office is pretty clever. He was supposed to be the one who dies, but Roy turned the role down. Instead, we get Sean, an interesting character, who dies. How sad. And is it me, or can you feel that Ellen is talking about Martin when she says "It's waited all this time and it came for him" and other phrases concerning Sean's death? Anyways, this movie has moments of bi-polar disorder, like when Ellen comes downstairs and is about to cook dinner, a bunch of pots fall and she's in an upset mood, saying "I want you to get out of the water!" and when Jake is yelling at Mike, he randomly stops and says "Sorry about your brother, man!" The shark was always a great part of the Jaws series. In Jaws 1 and 2, the shark was always memorable; in Jaws 3-D, the shark is pretty damn forgettable, since she's barely in it. It's all about boring humans. But in this one, it's shameless. It's pretty unforgettable, but for the wrong reason: The shark always has a "DURRRRR!" expression on it's face. It's always open-mouthed whenever you see it. I guess it has problems. Is that why it just randomly blows up when Ellen's boat hits it? Which reminds me, the ending fiasco is a real pain. The original ending was awesome! Sure, the shark looked like a dinosaur in some scenes and it looked a bit CGI in the scene where Ellen's boat tip hits it, but it still looked cool. It was spitting blood and everything. So after an unsettling feeling by the test audience, what happens? The ending is changed to a one that looks completely fake and makes no sense. So, Ellen's boat tip stabs the shark and it blows up for some reason. If you pause at the moment before it blows up, you can see how phony it looks. It looks like it was shot in a bathtub. The original ending at least made sense. The shark was stabbed and slowly fell down to it's death after the injury. In here, it's just... BOOM! When I was a kid I though the "bathtub" ending looked cool, but now... It looks stupid.

The flashbacks are like the flashbacks in D3: The Mighty Ducks, it just makes us wish we were watching the movie (or in D3's case, MOVIES) in which the clips were taking from. That also doesn't make sense. Ellen is the one having these flashbacks, specifically the scenes where Martin shoots the shark and where he bonds with Sean at dinner. She clearly wasn't there in those scenes, but yet she's having them.

The dream sequence is pretty non-sensical, as well. Ellen has a dream where she's swimming in the Bahamas, and the shark eats her. She doesn't like the water, so why would she be having a dream like this? Overall, this movie doesn't get me enraged like other things, but it's a mess. It's along the lines of "so bad, it's good" at moments.

Also, great touch on not doing the cliché of having the black guy die! That's a movie cliché that EVERYONE likes to point out and say that every film does it.

review_title: A great white shark is after the lives of the Brody family.Can they survive or go down to the murderous jaws one after another?
review_detailed_main: The worst Jaws movie I've ever seen. The shark roars like a tiger(I don't think a shark roars like that).Sean Brody's arm ripping scene was most idiotic to me.Another thing- can a shark know in which part of the earth you are in? In the movie the shark eventually followed Ellen Brody and her family to the Bahamas! The movie could do a bit better if it had Roy Schieder(or any other person in Martin Brody's role). The worst part is the climax.I actually could not understand the destruction of the shark.The shark was quite massive compared to the other sharks in the Jaws series.The sharks size was as huge as the sharks in the movie-DEEP BLUE SEA.But even though DBS had gone a bit further with it's action packed scenes.Another hating part is the kissing of Ellen & Hoagie.I had expected a lot better plot line from Michael De Guzman,the writer.The worst movie award should be handed over!

review_title: Legendary because of it's lame ending
review_detailed_main:
Furthermore there is nothing to say about this really bad movie. The acting is horrendous,especially by Lorraine Gray.

But the ending is,because it is so bad,very enjoyable to watch.

Still,of course,that don't make up for it. 1/10

If you were to ask a serious movie fanatic what some of the worst films of all time are, chances are they would include Jaws: The Revenge. Jaws: The Revenge is the fourth and final film in the Jaws franchise and was released in 1987. The film was directed by Joseph Sargent and stars Lorraine Gary, Lance Guest, and Michael Caine. The film still performed fairly decent at the box office but is the lowest performing film in the Jaws franchise. Now, this film was universally panned by critics and audiences. So much so that the film is often considered one of the worst films of all time.

We are back in Amity as we see one of the Brody brothers, Sean, gets killed by a shark. Mourning the loss of her husband and son, Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary) moves to the Bahamas with her son Michael. But the shark wants revenge and this time, it is personal.

I have seen this film a total of three times (as of the time that this review is being written) and I have come to the conclusion that this film is bad. The most recent viewing of this film, I decided to just turn my brain off and just let it all happen. It seems to work well that way I suppose but why should I do that? Even if I was to find any good, it seems insignificant because the negative aspects of this film are far, far, far, greater. Let me just put things into perspective here. Superman IV is worse than this film and if I could, would give it zero stars. This film, rightly deserves the one star rating that it will get from me. With Jaws: The Revenge, the only good thing I can truly say is that at least there are returning characters and the continuity seems to be picked right back up because it appears that this film may or may not ignore Jaws 3-D. But it is all still a big slap in the face to viewers who really enjoyed the first film. The film is highly absurd with it's plot that I am certain the film itself is aware of it's utter absurdness. The film likes to have our main character Ellen Brody to have sepia toned flashbacks of events that she never witnessed. Also, apparently there is an unexplained psychological connection between this shark and Ellen Brody. Apparently sharks are aware of the concept of revenge and somehow knows where a family is located by swimming from Amity to the Bahamas in a span of a couple of days. Those are just a few of a whole boatload (pun intended) of absurdities. If one is brave enough to watch this film, you will certainly find more. It is basically a given. The acting is not very good (though I can certainly say it is a minor improvement over the acting in Jaws 3-D). This film spends more time focusing on the characters and not really doing much with them. This film ends up being a sort of melodrama where a shark makes cameos. I feel bad for Michael Caine because this is one of those films that he worked on to just get a paycheck. Michael Caine just seems to be a really friendly person in general and I hate to see someone like him in a film like this. Gone is any sort of suspense. The music is not very good and as you may know, the original film relied on the music to effectively build suspense. This film's music for me, does not help build suspense and just feels off in key scenes. Lastly, the special effects are bad. People who know this film are aware of one infamous effect in this film so I just ask to see it for yourself if you are ever so curious. The shark itself oddly enough spends more time out of the water instead of in the water and looks even more fake.

I struggle with whether or not calling Jaws: The Revenge the worst film of all time. It is certainly not the number one worst film, but it certainly is up there.

review_title: The Movie should of been a comedy

review_detailed_main: How on God's green Earth did they manage to f*ck up Jaws this bad? Jaws 1 masterpiece. Jaws 2 decent, Jaws 3 the beginning of the end, and now Jaws 4 the Revenge... the final nail in the coffin. About everything is terrible about Jaws 4, especially the acting, characters, story (somehow the shark finds out of the Brody's vacation plans, and what a better place to get away from water than the Bahamas? God, even the music! The f*cking music has always been an icon. Not any more. So many things make no sense I could go on forever. I recommend seeing it only if you really, really want to complete the Jaws circle, if you're retarded or if you have a death wish.

review_title: Jaws: The Revenge succeeds in doing what it sets out to accomplish - scaring you to death.

review_detailed_main:
Wow. This movie is so insanely stupid that I don't know where to start. How about this... Universal is going to take an incredibly great movie classic and destroy it with idiotic sequels! Brillient! Sure, it may have grossed its budget, but thats all this movie was made to do. Its objective was to milk the American people out of more money.

I read here on IMDb.com, that Jaws: The Revenge had a budget of 23 Million dollars. Give me 1/16th of that budget and I'm positive that I could make a better film.

1.Sharks cannot roar. 2.Sharks cannot stand on their tails. 3. When sharks are impaled with large sticks they do not automatically explode. 4.Mama Brody cannot reminisce about things she didn't witness. 5.Sharks cannot follow people vast distances. 6.Sharks do not enjoy swimming in warm bahaman waters. 7.Michael Caine shouldn't be in this movie. 8.Sharks do not have feelings. I could really go on forever there. I enjoyed Jaws 2, its not a bad film. Jaws 3 is laughable, but still holds up. Jaws: The Revenge is simply a steaming heap of movie making feces. Judging by the cinematography alone (revealing the inner workings and external moving parts of the extremely fake hunk of plastic thats supposed to be a shark) the director gives Bruno Mattei a run for his money.

Do not buy or even rent this piece of cinematic garbage, unless you want to have a good laugh.

review_title: "They spend half their lives looking for food & the other half eating it." Absolutely terrible film, this one deserves all it's bad reviews...
A totally irrelevant and absurd final entry in the Jaws series.

review_detailed_main: Lorraine Gary is very hot for this final fight. She is like Sigourney Weaver on Aliens and Jamie Lee curtis on Halloween. She has to kill the shark for a last time. A lot of action and terror, Lorraine Gary is really a good actress, I like her.

review_title: Not as bad as everyone says
review_detailed_main:
OK, so maybe Jaws The Revenge isn't cinema at its finest. But, the amount of criticism levied to this film is ridiculous. I am admittedly a huge Jaws fan and have watched the original movie over 40 times. I have seen Jaws The Revenge possibly 25 times. I know that it isn't a classic by any means, but the movie really is good.

First off the acting. It wasn't terrible. Lorraine Gary did a terrific job as the lead. I felt sympathy for her and she does have some ability. Lance Guest as Michael was fantastic also. I am still waiting for him to get his break out role in Hollywood because I think he has potential. Mario Van Peebles brings some Bahamian humor, and it sheds some light onto the movie. And Michael Caine maybe isn't at his finest, but he is decent enough.

The cinematography is just beautiful. It just makes me want to go to the Bahamas every time I watch. The music score is better than the original. It has a sort of mystical, on the edge feel to it. It's too bad Michael Small didn't get any recognition for it, and anyone would be hard pressed to find the soundtrack, even though it's one of the finest ever.

Joseph Sargent does an okay job directing. I admit that it isn't anything special, but it's not trash. A lot of people have problems with the special effects and some of the things the shark does. Yes, the shark looks fake. That's a given when the film has such a low budget and the studio behind the picture isn't totally committed. There is one scene in particular that many have a problem with and that is when the shark is doing a so called stand on the water. It's obvious to me that the scene is in slow motion, and the shark is leaping from the water, which makes it appear to be standing on its fin. There are many aspects of the film also that are very authentic. An example is when the shark is attacking the boat and it's eyes roll back in its head, which is what a real great white would do.

The ending is terrible and totally brings down the film. But once again, I come with my defense. In Michael De Guzman's original script, the ending was much different and rather exciting. As I alluded to earlier, budget constraints kept this film from producing an adequate ending. If you are interested, there are many links on the Net with the original script.

Jaws the Revenge is a movie that I guess you have be a really big Jaws fan to enjoy. I know that it isn't perfect by any means and that it never will be considered to be a good movie by anybody other than the "Jaws Junkies." But, for all the people that like to tear it apart and dissect its every mistake, remember that it's only a movie and not real life. 6 Stars

review_title: I've had a better time waiting in line at the DMV
It was fun, not that bad

review_detailed_main: I've read the reviews here and concur that it was a terrible movie. The only thing that almost hypnotically drew me to it was Michael Caine. It was like watching John Wayne in Pantomine. I kept watching just to catch his performance, and then kept wondering why he did it in the first place. He must already have been a very rich man in 1987, and could not possibly have 'done it for the money'. Surely an actor must have to consider a box office hit in favour of a shed load of money. Not so here it would appear. I'm so disappointed Micheal! But, at the end of the day, it's just another case of over stretching a good idea. There ought to be a law concerning the making of sequels. They are invariably never at least as good as the original, given that that the original was that good to begin with. Even the 'Godfather' series suffered.

JAWS: THE REVENGE - what can be said? How about all of it's flaws:

--The shark that roars. --Michael Caine goes into the water and gets out....with a dry shirt!?!? --The cheap throwaway dialogue. --A traveling shark. --The bizarre dreams-? nightmares-? dreams within dreams? --No John Williams score... --No mention of Sea World or it's JAWS 3-D relations... --The fakest looking shark of the bunch. --The 2 endings -?

This film is a bonafide mess....AND a true laugh riot. If you are ever in a BAD BAD mood - watch this film - you will laugh your ass off. This film makes you in a great mood and you could make a drinking game out of this one as well. When someone says something that is considered nonsense - DRINK. You'll be drunk within 20 mins!

And let me finish by asking - why does the shark stay up above the water so long at the ending? That's not even scientifically possible. But then again is nothing featured in this UNIVERSAL STUDIOS release.

You read that right - they funded this, approved the script, and released it - were they drunk?

review_title: A rather bad but entertaining movie.
review_detailed_main:
I have seen much worse movies in my life. That said, this isn't a good movie at all! But it is also not that 1* movie many reviewers want to make you believe it is.

Acting is mostly believable, if it weren't for the character "Jake". I do accept the character only because he's not taking the whole thing very seriously, which is understandable because:

Effects and story are weak! Especially compared to the original jaws movies this one has a very unbelievably bad shark animatronic - which makes the whole movie feel trash-ish.

And that's what makes it so hilariously fun. The whole "serious" acting around a bad manufactured robot shark + the nonsense story is quite some fun. I enjoyed it and I think, if you don't take this movie to serious, you might be entertained as well.

I personally will never understand 1* rant-ratings. There are movies really worth 1*, this one isn't a 5+ but definitely not as bad as many other horror flicks. I think jaws 3D had a better story but, due to 3D, worse effects and no real connection to the jaws series. Both are a 3* to me.

review_title: The series that keeps getting better every movie

review_username: Jack Smith - The King Of Horror
review_detailed_main: I will never understand why there is so much hatred directed towards this film. It is the best of the "Jaws" sequels. It goes without saying that this film comes nowhere near to the standards of the original but it is great entertainment and is always good fun to watch. The direction is poor and Mario Van Peebles as the madcap scientist Jake is the only standout performer in the entire cast. You get to see some seriously nasty Shark Attacks which include arms being ripped off and the clear carribean oceans in which the majority of the action takes place are turned red with blood on more than one occassion which is a big plus. The one thing that stops this from being a really great movie is the ridiculous plot, you cannot seriously believe for one moment that the shark holds a grudge against the Brodie Family. This suggestion of the supernatural is more than a bit stupid and is impossible to overlook. Despite of this Jaws: The Revenge is still a very good film featuring the best Shark Attack scenes and Underwater Footage in the "Jaws" Series and the hilarious bonus of getting to see Michael Caine make a fool of himself and for these reasons alone is worth watching. Overall this is a good film that does not deserve the excessive criticism which it has got from so-called fans of the series and know-it-all film critics.

This movie might sound good at first but looks can be deceiving. This is by far the worst sequel to a good movie I have ever seen.The plot was OK but it was the special effects that made this movie horrible.I mean the shark was like a !%$#*@ puppet, I mean this movie had way worse special effects than the original Jaws and it was made 17 years later. I mean that just should'nt happen in todays film-making society.If this movie did'nt have the Jamaican guy this movie would TOTALLY suck.And even he dies, the guys you want to die like the old lady don't die but the Jamaican guy does I mean what is up with that? I would strongly advise you to not watch this,for it is inappropriate for young children and a dumb "horror" flick to adults.3/10 stars for the Jamacian guy.

review_title: I am a Micheal Caine fan--I enjoyed watching him.
The Shark was one step away from climbing out of the water and asking if they've seen any Brody's going around...
The tag-line should have been "This Time It's Pathetic"

review_detailed_main: You try and put them together but its like trying to put a shark shaped peg through a Dreyfuss shaped hole. Jaws and Jaws: The Revenge. Two movies, the SAME series and yet one is a classic and the first summer blockbuster and the other is, er, well...I'm not quite sure. We'll attempt to work out what it is together over the course of the next 300 words or so. Where to begin? No doubt the producers of 'The Revenge' asked themselves a similar question. What was left? Amity had endured two shark problems which is quite a lot for a small coastal town, especially a fictional one and they'd tried the Jaws in a different setting thing but it was curiously one-dimensional, even with 3-D glasses. You could of course just have another shark wander into the waters off Amity's shore but that night be construed as stretching credibility in some way so instead they came up with something quite wonderful and zoologically spurious - a vengeful shark with a murderous grudge against the Brody Family! Absolutely brilliant! Except that this is of course the most insanely misconceived idea in movie history. It's so bad that the only explanation for its passage to production is that someone pitched it as a kind of joke only to be horrified when the backers gave it a resounding thumbs up. Screenwriter Michael De Guzman who strangely hasn't subsequently become an A-list Hollywood scribe must have been too embarrassed to correct his bosses and so off he went and the result may be not just the worst sequel of all time but possibly one of the worst movies of all time. It does however introduce us to the most intelligent Shark in the history of the world. More cunning than his predecessors no.4 can set traps, learn the details of local law enforcement and manipulate certain people to come out on to the water, use its contacts on dry-land to find flight information on the Brody family and alter its own bio-chemistry to survive in warmer waters having swam some 3,000 miles to pursue the unlucky Brody brood. Is it any wonder Roy Scheider's character had a fatal heart attack? Teams of experts should be descending on the Bahamas to study the most unique animal that's ever lived but instead Michael Caine wants to kill it, which is baffling frankly. So the script isn't so much Quint as Jack Sparrow but at the least there's the taunt direction, the polished production values and the impeccable performances and if believe that you'll believe a Shark can roar.

review_title: a bad movie, but still WAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAY better than "Cruel Jaws"
This one should be shown in cinema schools, definitely
A very disappointing movie, but I can't say I was expecting much better.

review_detailed_main: I did like Jaws 4: The Revenge. I don't think there will a Jaws 5 bbecause the shark died at the end of the 4th movie. You can never beat the original movies, the first always is the best, but it is very rare that someone can do better like The terminator. I enjoyed the 2nd terminator movie better than the 1st because of the graphics and how they created the T-1000, how it looks like and what moves it can do. I give jaws 4: the revenge 10 out of 10.

review_title: Not the worst of the JAWS movies

review_detailed_main: This is one of the worst films I have seen to date. I gave it a "2" only because I actually made it through the entire movie. The shark looks fake, the actors are terrible, it is a big mess. If I remember correctly only the shark only takes out two people, when you want it to eat them all. Counting the hair on your arm would be a better use of your time than watching this stinker.

review_title: Not the best but by no means the worst!!!
Revenge of the 80's: The definite unnecessary sequel.
review_detailed_main:
Jaws: The Revenge (1987) has to be the worse sequel ever made for a good film. The JAWS series has gotten progressively worse over the years. After the debacle with the 3-D sequel, I didn't think that the producers could sink any lower. Well they have with this highly illogical and annoying sequel. All those involved with this project should lower their heads in shame. I have never seen such a terrible film. Okay I have, but this was a major released picture that actually was shot on film and played in movie theaters. The only one who should receive a pass is Maurice Micklewhite. At least he admits that he'll appear in anything that pays him a decent wage. A final nail into the JAWS legacy. Let's hope that there will be no more sequels made. Finger crossed people.

Not recommended at all.

review_title: One of the worst films ever/ Shark looks fake
review_detailed_main: Not only the worst film in the series, but one of the worst films ever made. You would think after three previous efforts they would at least make the shark look real. I used to play with a toy shark that looked more real.

review_title: Everything has been said but we must say it all again
review_detailed_main:
"This movie sucks" "I hate this movie" "i can't believe what i just saw" Typical reviews to this stupidity parade called Jaws: The Revenge. And the sad thing is it's all understandable. I still HATE this movie, so much! I'm like Burce Wayne, even after avenging his parents death the rage and fight is still there. Even after writing an argession filled review three years ago, i still have to come back here every few months to read these same reinforcing hate filled reviews. Because no matter how many times a reviewer points out that a SHARK stands on its tail and roars my head can never fathom the earth-shattering stupidity of it all. Bruce Wayne will never get his parents back, I will never get my 90 minutes back, and the scar left on the name of a groundbreaking piece of cinema will never heal.

I'll forgo the instinctual impossibility that a shark would camouflage himself near a piece of driftwood to eat a person on a boat rather than just swim up and eat another fish. I'll forgo the logistical impossibility that a shark fearing widow would flee her island home to ANOTHER ISLAND! As I type this I just watched today's best NHL goaltender come out of his zone, drop his stick and let an open ice puck crawl right between his legs for a goal in the Stanley Cup finals. So people make stupid mistakes in times of pressure, I'll forgive you Ms. Brody, just as I forgave Mr. Brodeur. After all what brings more pressure than a telepathic, reborn, teleporting, roaring, exploding, vengeful predator of the seas? I'll even forgo the physical impossibility of surviving the bends.

This ending, although cannot be forgiven by Jesus Christ himself. The last twenty minutes is just an unbelievable orgy of every irrational idea conceived by filmmakers. There was a method behind Spielberg's exiting finale in 1975. He said that by that point he "has his audience." After taking them on this thrilling yet conceivable ride, that for just a few seconds they would suspend their beliefs and allow a great white to swim around chewing on an oxygen tank. Well he was right. Maybe the makers of Jaws: The Revenge had a reverse plan... maybe their plan was to constantly bombard you with inconceivable acts of stupidity and impossibility until you are rendered retarded from the whole ordeal so when they unleash a plethora of insanity at the climax you barely realize it.

Can there be any other excuse for a shark to walk on its hind fins, roar, catch a man in his razor sharp mouth in slow motion, let him survive, get poked by a stick, and explode!? Ok let us look at this systematically. A shark on its hind fins: Maybe they were trying to out-do the original scene where Bruce capsizes the Orca. "Well a shark lunging out of the water to surface onto an already half-sunken, half decaying boat is pretty amazing. Let's do something really amazing!" Too much of a good thing, no wonder this is a sequal. And what they can't "improve" on from the original, they just steal. Just random scenes of the original thrown in the movie, as if to say "Hey, she's saying the same thing her husband said while fighting a shark, what a great example of.." bullshit! it's pointless and only reminds me of what film I SHOULD be watching! And she's not heroically surviving one last face to face battle with the predator armed with only a rifle. She's on a huge boat with all her surviving friends and family about to poke the gravity defying fish that's wearing some flash cube. Not exciting at all, it's pathetic! Two last comments before I finish... why would they make the shark roar? I suppose the filmmakers knew they weren't gifted enough to make a giant hungry silent eating machine about to attack be scary, so they made it roar to add "a scary sound effect." You know in slasher movies when they just make a nail-on-chalkboards sound whenever the murderer pops out? That kind of cheap garbage. But they can't have someone just scream, or have a loud wave crashing sound. No, it has to be this insanely thoughtless roar. Finally, the explosion. Have you ever seen that Simpsons gag where something clearly stable and inflammable like a shopping cart crashes and explodes? That satirical gag is EXACTLY what this movie pulls, and wants you to seriously accept it! Try to think about that fact logically for more than a minute and don't blame me when you regain consciousness. To see something like this even referred to as a serious idea is inconceivable for even half a second!

Well, as I finish this review, the Devils paid for their mistake and lost the game. So that piled on all these horrible factors that equal Jaws The Revenge, i must retire before i simply throw my computer out the window. To conclude, I hate this movie, you should hate this movie. And it is NOT healthy to imagine Spielberg making a sequel to "save" this franchise. It should have never been a franchise anyway. It was a wonderful suspenseful work of art about nature, fear, and survival; and now the name is synonymous with monumental acts of stupidity and ridiculousness. Please, enough damage has been done.

That's a line from "Jaws 2" when a second shark attacks Amity. However, according to this one, sharks DO take things personally. This movie pretends that "Jaws 3" never happened. Sean Brody (Mitchell Anderson) is the police chief of Amity--his other brother Mike (Lance Guest) works with Jamaican Jake (Mario van Peebles) in the Bahamas. Sean is killed by a shark (who supposedly set up the trap!!!) and his mother Ellen (Lorraine Gary) is positive the shark is targeting the whole family (!!!). Mike brings her to the Bahamas to recover...but the shark follows. Ellen knows this because she has a telepathic link with the shark (!!!!!).

Yep, it's as stupid as it sounds. It starts out OK with Sean being attacked and killed--and Anderson was actually very good in his role-- but I'd like to know HOW the shark was able to set it all up. It moves to the Bahamas and falls apart swiftly. First off, two white sharks were killed in the first two movies. What is this one? A cousin of them? Second--Gary having a "link" to the shark is just absurd. Third--van Peebles (a good actor) has to use an annoying accent and if he had said "mon" one more time I would have screamed; fourth--Michael Caine pops up as "Hoagie"--he deserves better; fifth--the shark looks fake; sixth--watch for the scene where Caine is pulled out of the water...and is completely dry and seventh--the ending is annoying stupid and abrupt. Also Gary looks terrible--but it fits the movie I suppose.

On the plus side--Guest and Caine are very good and the Bahamas location looks breath-taking. Still that doesn't excuse the ludicrous script and lousy acting from everyone else. And van Peebles "comic" lines are painfully unfunny.

At least Caine and Guest have excuses for making this--Caine said it was for a free trip to the Bahamas and Guest said he did it to work with Caine. Still, this can safely be skipped completely. A sad ending to what started out as a great series. A 1.

review_title: "I have an irresistible urge to kiss you, Ellen Brody."
Just when you thought it was safe to go back to the movies...
review_detailed_main: Why shouldn't this be the worst film ever? Sure, it's in focus, and it's got Sir Michael in it, but apart from that this is absolutely the bottom of the chum barrel. Let's forget the ropey plot and the hilarious special effects. Beyond all that, we have the pain of actually watching the tortured cast struggle through the inane script. Horrible horrible horrible, made even worse for the fact that it's made as a sequel to one of Hollywood's best. I wish I could give it none out of ten. Thankfully, though, there was no Jaws five. perhaps the shark could have eaten whatever studio heads greenlighted this load of manure.

When Ellens son Sean Brody is killed by a great white shark, Michael invites her to stay with him in the Bahamas over Christmas. While Michael undergoes work as a Marine Boiologist, he is confronted with the shark who resurfaces once more...

I was hoping to see a mass improvement after Jaws 3, but the series got a whole lot worse. Normally sequels ruin the aspect of the original film, but I didn't think it was possible with Jaws. Having a giant shark in the water would surely scare anyone, but the only thing lurking in the water for Jaws the revenge, is a bunch of plastic cogs.

There's nothing natural about the shark, it moves too mechanically and even roars, not too mention the indescribable end scene when the shark blows up by getting stabbed by a piece of wood...

Its obvious that this film was a desperate attempt to scare us once more by doing everything and anything possible...

review_title: Brought The Series Back to Life
review_detailed_main: Many People call this Film another Silly Sequel, but I Think It Was way more than that. I Think it Brought the Series back to life after a Rather Slow Third Installment. The Idea That Sharks can Carry out Revenge is the Only Bizarre thing about the Whole Movie. Good Scares and High Excitement make this Film a Must See!

review_title: A much maligned, yet entertainingly daft sequel
review_detailed_main:
Lorraine Gary returns as Ellen Brody, whose son Sean is killed by a shark in the waters off Amity Island. She moves to the Bahamas to get away from things but...the shark follows her!

Jaws: The Revenge is the third and final sequel to Jaws (1975). It's a film that almost requires no introduction on account of its reputation as such a monumental mess of a movie. It's easy to see why it attracted such scorn to be fair as its story-line about a shark that has the ability to follow someone – presumably via psychic powers – hundreds of miles, it's beyond ridiculous; while what the shark is precisely seeking revenge for is never fully explained. The great white itself is notable for having the unusual ability to roar like a lion, which is at the very least an unexpected skill given sharks have no vocal chords. But you know what, I consider all of the above nonsense as positive aspects which go in this film's favour. Its sheer ridiculousness kind of makes it so entertaining. The real drawback to Jaws: The Revenge in my book was the excessive amounts of tedious melodrama which accounted for quite a bit of the run-time of the middle third of the movie. But whenever the shark popped up to play, things got a lot more agreeable and thankfully he appears pretty often throughout. And while it did look fake, the shark sort of still looked quite cool nevertheless. Essentially all the attack scenes are good value in my opinion and, aside from some fast-editing used in the earlier moments, I thought the cinematography was actually more than decent in capturing those moments rather effectively.

Famously Michael Caine missed out picking up his Oscar for Hannah and Her Sisters (1986) in order to film one of the re-shot endings for this. The one I saw has Mario Van Peebles character ludicrously survive being pulled down into the depths of the ocean while clamped into the jaws of the shark - he tiresomely re-emerges with a few light scratches and several wise-cracks. The actual destruction of the shark itself was also somewhat unclearly achieved as well but what the hell. It's such a silly film that such issues become relatively moot points by its conclusion. Also of note was the blink-and-you'll-miss-her re-appearance of Lee Fierro reprising her role as Mrs. Kinter, so memorable as the mother of the little boy who was killed on the beach in the first movie, leading to her angry and emotional dockside confrontation with Chief Brody. In this one she now appears to be a friend of the Brody family, so bygones must be bygones.

Despite its reputation, I definitely prefer this sequel to the somewhat annoying previous entry, Jaws 3D (1983). It does feel like more of a continuation of the story, even if it takes the characters into an extremely silly direction. But the sharksploitation genre has produced films over the subsequent years that have rarely been known for their understatedness and intelligence. Jaws: The Revenge is no different, it just achieves the same level of daftness on a massively bigger budget. The honest truth is that this is definitely much more enjoyable than the majority of other shark-attack monster movies.

Ridiculously retarded Jaws movie where the plot revolves around a shark that is out for revenge on a specific family. This shark is apparently smart enough to track these people thousands of miles. The family is that of Martin Brody from the first two Jaws movies. Thankfully Roy Scheider had too much dignity to be a part of this, so his character is dead. His widow, played by shameless Lorraine Gary, has a new boyfriend in Michael Caine. Gross. The real hero of the movie is the Last Starfighter himself, Lance Guest. Please don't blame him for this monstrosity. We are all still in his debt for that time he saved the universe. It's a terrible movie, moronic on every level. Mario Van Peebles is in it! That alone should tell you to avoid this like the plague.

This is hard to put into words how terrible this film is. The acting is awful, the story is tripe, the effects are a joke and this film just makes a complete mockery of the first 2 films. Jaws 3 was trash as well. No wonder Roy Scheider didnt act in this movie, Michael Caine did, and I bet hes been regretting that decision ever since.

You can see the actual machinery in the shark which the editor of director of the film obviously either couldnt be bothered or didnt have the talent to spot. A massive gaping hole with pullys and levers can be visibly seen as the 'shark' is chasing Brodys son into that ship wreck. Also, when did sharks grin?, the state of the sharks mouth is a joke, not to mention the roar of it, near the end of the film. I thought it was going to turn green and into the incredible hulk it roared that loud!.

If they would have made this movie into a comedy then it would have been plausible and acceptable. Surely they cannot possibly expect a half intelligent audience to take this criminal film seriously??!!.

Jaws for me, is only 2 films long. Jaws 2 was okay, mainly because Roy Scheider in it (not that I think much of him in Seaquest), the original Jaws was sheer genius. Fantastic film.

Avoid Rubber Jaws:The Revenge, at all costs, except if you are feeling depressed and could do with a good laugh.

Rating 0.5/10

review_title: A disgrace to the series SPOILER ALERT!

review_detailed_main: Of coarse this is the worst Jaws movie made not to mention one of the worst movies ever in general, that's common knowledge. I do have to say it is surprising just how unrealistic this movie is though. In the assumed senecio that the shark swims all the way to the Bahamas to follow Ellen is unrealistic enough but a theory I had in which there just so happens to be a different rough shark in where Ellen is staying at the Bahamas would be just as unrealistic. Want to waist an hour and thirty two minutes of your life, watch this.

review_title: Not as bad as some would have you think.
review_detailed_main: There is a surprising number of people who seem to hate this movie for strange reasons. The main one seem to be they don't think its realistic, as if any of the other Jaws movies were! The concept of Jaws:The Revenge is that the family from the original movie are seemingly being targeted by great white sharks in revenge for the deaths of the sharks from the other movies. What I find strange is that this very same plot had been used in the movie Orca which no one seemed to take issue with, but because its Jaws somehow everyone has a problem with it? The other big criticism is that Michael Caine is in the movie and his acting is bad, it isn't. Also we have complaints about Mario Van Peebles Jamaican accent, again its not that bad. The movie itself is not great but its certainly not as bad as some people want it to be. It may be the weakest of the franchise but not by much, what it is not is a carbon copy of the first two movies which seems to be what some people wanted for four times over. Most of the reviews on here are exaggerated at how bad this movie is, some people obviously havent seen a truly bad movie. This has a decent story line, decent effects, decent acting and some gory deaths. What else do you want in a shark movie?

The final movie in the "Jaws" franchise. And what a way to go out, huh? I know that this movie is widely disliked, but I have to admit that I have always enjoyed it, since watching it as a kid in the late 1980s. But then again, I've always enjoyed the "Jaws" franchise and shark-themed movies in general.

Sure, the storyline in "Jaws: The Revenge" is not the most well-written, and looking at it objectively it is quite far out there. I mean, a migrating shark hunting a single person, well it is just beyond the realms of possibilities, isn't it? Regardless, I still found the movie to be adequately entertaining for the campy fun that it is. Writer Michael De Guzman put together a fair enough script and storyline for the movie. Sure, it has its flaws, but it is entertaining nonetheless.

It is nice to see Lorraine Gary return to reprise the role of Ellen Brody. But aside from her, the cast ensemble in "Jaws: The Revenge" is all newcomers to the franchise. There are some familiar faces on the cast list, however, with the likes of Michael Caine and Mario Van Peebles.

The special effects in "Jaws: The Revenge" are actually fair enough. It is a "Jaws" movie, so you know what you are getting. And while the movie doesn't have a slow moving shark outlined in a shroud of black, as in the "Jaws 3-D" movie, it does, however, have a shrieking shark. Yeah, I kid you not.

"Jaws: The Revenge", from director Joseph Sargent, actually is a guilty pleasure movie, I will admit that.

My rating of the 1987 movie "Jaws: The Revenge" lands on a five out of ten stars.

Although it is hard to watch a Jaws movie without Roy Scheider, this is an okay movie. It isn't as bad as some people make it out to be, it is good to watch solely to see how the characters have grown up. Some parts can be quite annoying,yes, but you have to at least give it a try.

Is it just me, but are not only these movies getting worse, but so are the effects. Didnt effects improve over 12 years between Jaws and Jaws 4? If this movie had a 23 million dollar budget, where did it go? Caine? Bahamas filming locations? The construction of Universals Falls Lake in Hollywood? One good thing about this film would have to be Lorraine Gary's performance. She has a great presance in these films, and it is fun to watch her go after the shark. But the story, effects, and supporting acting make this movie flat out ridiculous.

review_title: Why was this movie even made?

review_detailed_main: "Jaws: The Revenge" (1987), all of you know how much I loathe "Jaws 3-D" (1983). That film has a poorly conceived and executed storyline with mediocre special effects. Now, that being said, "Jaws 3-D" is a masterpiece compared to this worthless and retarded pile of filth! "Jaws: The Revenge" has a predictable yet confusing story, the acting is a joke, the special effects are garbage, and the soundtrack is cliched! The plot is, Ellen Brody is now a widow since Martin Brody died of fear between the third and fourth film. Then, after Sean dies from a shark attack a grief-stricken Ellen and she her family move from Amity down to the Bahamas where a great white shark actually follows them, seeking revenge. Yeah, it's every bit as dumb as it sounds. I may not be a fan of any of the "Jaws" movies, but the fact that a Martin Brody is killed off due to fear of fighting a shark is insulting to his character. That's about as lazy as you can get! It was their excuse for him not appearing in this "film". Then, after Ellen tells her family to stay away from the water, they decide to move to the Bahamas and be completely surrounded by water. Finally, to top it all off, the shark actually follows them from the United States to the Bahamas! I honestly couldn't finish typing the storyline aspects without laughing. This is easily, one of the worst plots I have ever heard of in any movie. There is no suspense, no thrills and on top of that, the story is boring! What were the writers thinking?! How does the shark know about the Brody family? Why did they move to the Bahamas where there's even more water than at Amity?! All right, I think I've ranted on about the story long enough. As for the acting, it's nothing short of dreadful, from the whole cast. Not even Michael Caine could save it! Yep, somehow he got bribed to be in this "film". He's the only one who appears to be putting forth some sort of effort with his acting. That being said, effort doesn't always result in a good performance. This is, in my opinion, Michael Caine's worst acting performance out of all his movies! Don't even get me started on the name of his character. His name in this "film" is, Hoagie. I guess Sub, Grinder or Grilled Cheese were already taken? Come on, writers, you seriously couldn't come up with any other name? Like, I don't know, a human name? All of the acting is an embarrassment, but the worst performance comes from Lorraine Gary as Ellen Brody. Her acting is, without a shadow of a doubt, some of the worst I have ever seen in any movie, I'm not kidding. Why did she deserve her own starring role and "film"? No one cared for her character in the other films, including me! Fun-fact, Lorraine Gary was married to the President of Universal Studios at the time. Maybe that had something to do with it? On top of that, her character is so annoying and obnoxious, that I was rooting for the shark to eat her! Really, whenever I saw her precious face show up on the screen, I wanted someone to slap her! Granted, I'm sure that she's a nice person in real-life. But, when she's on the screen, she sucks! All of the acting is terrible. As for the special effects, I have a lot to say about them. However, I'll keep it short, sweet and to the point. They suck! There are very few that are adequate, but the majority of them are trash. The worst special effect is the shark itself. You can see the hinges in it's mouth, the harness holding it up in the air, etc. Plus, are you ready for this? Jaws roars in this "movie". I'm serious, the shark roars! Did elementary school students write this script? Although, to tell you the truth, I think children would've been better screenwriters than the wastes of life who vomited out the screenplay! Sharks don't roar, they cannot roar, it's impossible. They don't have lungs, or vocal cords. At this point, an unborn fetus is probably smarter than these incompetent writers! The special effects are nothing short of a joke. There are endless logical errors and flaws that are so bad, that you can't help but laugh. In one scene, Michael Caine's character swims in the water and as soon as he climbs into the boat, his shirt is completely dried. I'm not joking with you. When I first saw that part, I actually shouted: "What?!" But, I immediately burst into laughter just as fast as I yelled, if not faster! That's barely scratching the surface as far as how bad the special effects were. Some of them were so horrible, that I said to myself: "was the budget $100.00, and $99 dollars went to the actors' salaries?!" Finally, the soundtrack is a disaster. It's about as generic and cliched as you can get. There is nothing redeemable in this film score at all! Now, let's get to the only good element in this piece of garbage, the sets/locations. They give a good atmosphere, but that one positive is just simply outweighed by the negatives. "Jaws: The Revenge" is easily one of the worst films I have ever seen. The only thing that keeps it off my top ten worst movies list, is the fact that it makes me laugh and that it actually merits a one-star rating. That being said, for a film to qualify for my top ten worst movies list, it has to have zero stars. For some reason, this "film" manages to salvage one out of me. It's a miracle! Even then, I'm struggling to give this "movie" 1 out of 5 stars on my scale, which equates to 2 out of 10 IMDB stars. For the sake of your decency and intelligence, stay away from "Jaws: The Revenge". Thankfully, it's the last one in this apparent franchise. I'm actually embarrassed for it. Although, this film isn't even worth being embarrassed for at all! All of the "Jaws" movies are a total waste of time, especially "Jaws: The Revenge". Everyone involved with this worthless "movie" deserves to be eaten by sharks!

Second sequel to the 1975 blockbuster jaws, as the movie ignores the events of jaws 3, the plot in this movie is beyond stupid , the idea wouldnt even make it on an episode of the twilight zone , a great white shark following a potential victim from new jersey to the bahamas ???? Please!!! a vengeful telekenetic shark ??? uh, how did the writers dream this rubbish up? its unbelievable the film ruins the legacy of the original and pulls the curtains on the entire franchise, the producers should have left the brody family out of this production and take the franchise in another direction , which was already tired by the end of jaws 2 , some missed opportunities because the writers chose to leave the same characters in a long drawn out story which was barely believable by jaws 2 but jaws the revenge has no excuse they could have come up with something better than this drivel, apart from a good music score and a poignant scene mirroring a scene from the original , this is definately ONE of the worst films of all time !

review_title: Not the Worst Movie! Just the Worst Jaws
review_detailed_main:

The writing is far-fetched, and the shark special effects are a bit cheesy and over the top. With that said, it does a good job advancing the story of parts 1 and 2, the best movies in the series A must-see for fans of 1 and 2. Part 3 was pretty different!

In the Bahamas, Jaws stalks his prey all the way from Amity Island. The premise of a personal vendetta of shark vs. Humans is pretty ridiculous. But that is the main reason for my low score.

Still, the death scenes are entertaining, and the climax is possibly the silliest of all ending, but still entertaining albeit unbelievable.

review_title: It's bad, but it's not *that* bad
