It makes little sense, though to be fair it is from a franchise that is all about a huge human-killing shark; despite sharks, in fact, not actually being all that keen on our rotten flesh.

Michael Caine is somehow in this. Well, I say somehow... a trip to the Bahamas and a nice paycheck likely made it entirely logical from his view; as he reportedly stated himself. Lorraine Gary, meanwhile, spearheads an average support cast. Speaking of whom, I did find their dialogue and interactions to be very unnatural and forced.

5*. There are many, many worse films out there though.

Yeah, you gotta love Bruce the Shark! He has made 4 appearances on the big screen: - "Jaws" (the best of the series) - "Jaws 2" (the death of a dream!) - "Jaws 3D" (He looked like a giant loaf of bread at the end!) - This movie (Bruce finally roars because he's had enough of that pressure the humans put upon him!) This movie, along with the three others, are so good! It made Spielberg a genius with this and all his other films! What a great man! Do watch all the "Jaws" movies from beginning to end and, you too, will be smiling! (Just hope you don't have a scuba tank in your mouth and some madman doesn't shoot that tank or you'll explode!)

review_title: Based on a Really Dumb Premise
review_detailed_main: After her son "Sean Brody" (Mitchell Anderson) is killed by a great white shark in the waters off of Amity, New York, "Ellen Brody" (Lorraine Gray) flies to the Bahamas where her other son "Michael Brody" (Lance Guest) works as a marine biologist. Once there she gets premonitions of the great white shark coming after both her and Michael to order to get its revenge on them for one reason or another-it's not really clear. But what is clear is that this movie is based on a really dumb premise. I mean, let's face it, sharks don't take things personally! So to base an entire film around this ridiculous concept is just plain crazy. Add to that the fact that the scenes on land were extremely dull and essentially what is left is an incredibly boring--if not ludicrous-film. On the other hand the tropical scenery was nice and Lynn Whitfield (as "Louisa") was equally pleasant to look at as well. Unfortunately, those two qualities were hardly enough to lift this film into marginal territory. That said I have to rate this movie as below average.

review_title: This is Not a Bad Movie !
Come on, Michael Caine is in it...
review_detailed_main: Michael Caine is at least somewhat humorous. Oh wait, its a movie about a shark eating people. Its not supposed to be humorous. But it is, its quite laughable, and actually the special effects are more humorous than any of the characters. Except Ellen Brody, of course. Lorraine Gary's performance is...well, melodramatic (I suppose with the tragic death of her husband, she should be). Really, her performance is inspired...by needing money, I suppose. Maybe she had a heroin addiction to feed. Doubtless, she made millions from this film. I'm sure that the famous Joseph Sargent (who was mostly a TV director and has never actually made a decent film) thought that the script was money, and the film would make his career. Or end it (he has not directed a film since, only television). All in all, Jaws: The Revenge is an epic (as epic as a flatulent attack) end to an exciting motion picture quadrilogy. I'm still waiting for the nine-disk boxed set, complete with the 3-D version of number 3 (which is quite possibly even worse than Revenge).

The fourth and last official "Jaws" movie to date boosts supporting player Lorraine Gary to star status as the now widowed Ellen Brody. In the early minutes of the movie, her younger son, Sean (Mitchell Anderson), now a deputy, is gobbled up by yet another killer great white, prompting her to believe that that particular species simply has it in for her whole family. Despite this, she accepts the invitation of her older son Michael (Lance Guest) to stay with him and his family in the Bahamas, where - surprise, surprise - he works as a marine biologist. Yes, despite everything that happens to them, this stupid family just won't stay out of the water. And yes, you guessed it...the *same* shark that ate Sean tracks the Brodys to the Bahamas.

The patently absurd script by Michael de Guzman is the worst flaw in this lackluster effort. The filmmakers actually go out of their way to show the shark as often as possible, which only serves to point up how obviously phony it is. There is, for the most part, a sufficient lack of tension, and the main reason why "Jaws: The Revenge" would be entertaining at all is because it's so laughable. Gary, sporting a none too flattering hairdo, does take herself pretty seriously, but the other cast members certainly don't look too happy to be there; Mario Van Peebles speaks in a ridiculously unconvincing accent, and Michael Caine offers his effortless charisma to a supporting role as a pilot who tries to romance Gary. It may not be a great role, but his presence in anything is always welcome. One worthy component is the music score by Michael Small; both adapting John Williams' legendary themes and adding his own compositions, he helps to make the scenes just a little bit better. Admittedly, this is also shot rather well (by John McPherson).

Like many bad movies before and after it, "Jaws: The Revenge" is a compelling train wreck in spite of itself.

Five out of 10.

Pretty bad, although does has some good actors in it.

One to miss.

review_title: While Generally The Less Popular Installment, This Is Perhaps The Second Best!
review_detailed_main:
Most Jaws fans hate this installment, but I think the reason behind this emotion is more that this installment marks the end of the franchise, rather than because the movie was not worthy.

The story is not afraid to admit its previous mistakes, returns us to the beginning when the franchise was awesome, and revisits old characters, while introducing us to new ground. And it works!

Michael Caine is, as usual, stellar; but it is the return of Lorraine Gary as Ellen Brody that makes this chapter of the saga truly remarkable. Her performance, the story itself, and the fantastic effects-generated atmosphere truly uplift this could-be lackluster sequel into the annals of creature feature greatness.

review_title: "What could be more terrifying than Jaws: The Revenge?"
S for Shark, V for Vendetta and C for Crap.
review_detailed_main:
Alas, Jaws: The Revenge; the fourth (count them) Jaws film and third successfully insignificant sequel to that of Spielberg's fantastic 1975 film Jaws but Jaws: The Revenge shouldn't just be compared to that of Jaws but also to that of any other film ever made in terms of quality. Jaws: The Revenge on its own is not even entertaining enough to be a second rate monster movie like an Anaconda (1997) or a Deep Rising (1998) or something along those lines.

The things wrong with Jaws: The Revenge just spill off the screen like a barrel of grease down a water slide  anything that CAN go wrong in terms of logistics, what we're seeing or even the entire premise in the first place; DOES go wrong. Early on one character actually states about how the thought of the shark coming back for revenge on the Brody family is simply impossible  you know that and I know that  shark's don't know who's who on land so the fact one of the characters openly denies the fact this plot is even feasible on screen is mind blowingly backward film-making on its own merit.

Another problem with this film is just its basic content which is split into two different pieces: dialogue on the land, sea or in the air and action scenes. A lot of the dialogue scenes at least to me just seemed pointless and to be honest, were rather dull. Examples of this are: the scene on the beach in the Caribbean as Ellen looks out to sea in a silly 'I know you're out there' sort of a way, the sea bed digging scene involving Michael Brody (Martin's son) as he looks for sea snails or something (we don't need to know what he does for a living) and the new year's eve party which serves as an overly long and tedious scene where the outcome is just Hoagie (Michael Caine) admitting some sort of a feeling for Ellen  this whole love side plot was very out of place and in the end, so pointless that the film could've chopped the whole new years eve part out.

So many things backfire on so many levels, it's incredible. The fact we need to stomach this shark is actually out for 'revenge' against the Brody family and that it can swim from Amity to the Caribbean as well as pinpoint where it is the Brody family are now living; the fact the child is smart enough to recognise Ellen is called evasive by her mother and be able to imply it herself when Ellen is actually being evasive in front of her yet is not smart enough to know that you 'fly' a plane and not 'drive' it; the way in which Michael, Jake (van Peebles) and the rest of the characteristically non existent Caribbean crew are stupid enough to continue whatever pointless exercise it is they're doing even though the shark has struck  Jake even wants to go after it bringing back rehashed ideas Jaws 3-D had when the water-world employees wanted to capture it for their park.

If there is any saving grace it's the finale where the shark and the characters do battle on a little boat that Ellen took out on her own  something I still can't fathom the logic behind. The film borrows so heavily from the first Jaws film that the flashbacks involved are practically retelling the way the first film concluded and as a result, it feels like we're watching the first film's climax! With continuity problems abound, an insane and impossible premise as well as a really comic atmosphere and rather bland film-making, Jaws: The Revenge is the slow and painful death of what was the Jaws franchise.

So this is what a train wreck looks like..."Jaws The Revenge" is the fourth and, not suprisingly, final installment of the famous "Jaws" series. All right so the series isn't really famous, so much as the first one is. I haven't seen the middle two, but I don't think that would have helped me comprehend this weird movie any more than I did.

Now I understand that movies, especially horror movies, call for the suspension of disbelief. Skeptics could say I'm jaded, but I disagree. I do suspend disbelief, to an extent. When I see a "shark cam" shot, I accept that. When the shark cam shot is above water and we cut to a wide shot of just the fin sticking out the water, my suspension disappears. Unless Jaws is a super-shark, he has no eyes on his fin.

Then again, maybe he is, given the laughable behavior of this crazed fish in the movie. The essential plot is that this shark is still on the loose after all these year, even though I'm pretty sure it's been killed at the end of every single movie. I guess it decided it was tired of being killed by the Brody family (Stars of all the "Jaws" movies), so he decided to start offing Brodies one by one. The wife of Sheriff Brody, Ellen, is the only one who believes that the shark is out to get her and her family. Well, you know, it sounds so logical that I cannot imagine why anyone would disbelieve her!

I tried to understand this movie, I really did. But it is so completely devoid of talent and thought that it's impossible not to laugh at its total stupidity. The fin-cam is just the tip of the iceberg. Jaws not only can spot his prey well out of the water, and even on boats, but he can nimbly hop out of the water, up to the deck to chomp on his victims before quickly returning to the depths. And let's not forget Ellen's recollections of scenes she didn't even witness! The shark is so intent on revenge, that he swims from Long Island to the Bahamas in about two days. Someone sign that fish up for the Olympics! And the climactic confrontation with the shark is edited so poorly, I honestly couldn't tell you what happened. I know the characters lived, but as for Jaws, it's a big bloody mystery to me.

While making the first "Jaws," director Steven Spielberg realized his shark didn't look very realistic. So he intentionally kept it out of sight through the whole movie. I guess the director here had a little more confidence in his aquatic creation, because you see a lot of the shark in the movie. Of course, the thing looks as fake as ever, maybe even more so now given the ridiculous situations he is forced into. The worst detail about the fake shark? It always, always, has its mouth gaping wide open. I just felt like I was looking at something someone made in shop class.

Again, this movie is dumb and goofy and ridiculous. If you're looking for a scary movie like the first "Jaws," rent the first "Jaws." Looking for that here will only cause you great pain and discomfort. If you're watching to see how NOT to make a movie about a revenge obsessed shark, well, look no further.

This might be one of the worst movies I have ever seen. Spielberg's classic has been destroyed to such a deformed state. No movie has infuriated me, and made me laugh at it's stupidity like this before.

review_title: One of the most inept theatrical releases of the 80s.
review_detailed_main:
Lorraine Gary, whose husband is one of the head honchos at Universal Pictures (the company behind the entire JAWS series), reprises her pretty useless and uninteresting role from the first two films in this ridiculous, contrived and shockingly inept conclusion to the JAWS saga.

Gary plays Ellen Brody, the recently widowed wife of the late Sheriff Brody who believes that the great white from the original (yeah, the same one that was blown into a zillion pieces) is after her and her two sons. After one son is picked off near Martha's Vineyard, she and her surviving son (Lance Guest) flee to the Bahamas to escape, but the clever (and apparently, psychic) shark follows. Everything leads up to an unbelievable finale of the selfless Ms. Brody taking a solo trip out to sea to sacrifice herself so all the killing will stop!

Michael Caine (!) is wasted in a romantic subplot as a pilot (in fact he skipped out accepting his Oscar for HANNAH AND HER SISTERS because he was on location filming this).

Score: 1 out of 10 (AWFUL!)

I don't want to reveal how the film ends (though I don't recommend seeing it anyway), but Mrs. Brody has a bunch of flashbacks from the ending of the classic original "Jaws" (despite the fact she wasn't at those scenes) and somehow saves the day. Michael Cain wasted his time on this one...even the portrait of Roy Scheider (great actor, played Chief Brody in the first and second "Jaws" flicks) must be ashamed.

review_title: Jaws: The Revenge by Joseph Sargent
review_detailed_main: The Universal Studios wanted to move on with Jaws Franchise, as Jaws 3-D did well at the box office. But the next story would not use the elements from Jaws 3-D, instead they would use elements from the first Jaws. It would be interesting to see how the next story would be developed, by using elements from the first chapter which is still iconic. But the only actress to be back for the next Jaws movie, is Lorraine Gary who appeared in the first and the second one as Ellen Brody. The rest of the cast never appeared, in any previous Jaws movies neither did Michael Caine. In 1987 came out Jaws: The Revenge by Joseph Sargent, with Lorraine Gary and Michael Caine. The movie's plot: Martin Brody's widow Ellen Brody would confront a great white shark, that is seeking vengeance by following her to the Bahamas. As the movie is the last establishment of Jaws franchise, there have been expectations to surprise the audience and the critics. Instead it completely failed by becoming, a much worse Jaws chapter than the third one. The movie has a rhythm to be boring and predictable, which unnecessarily repeat some elements from Jaws by Steven Spielberg. The attack scenes didn't work to be suspenseful, but it worked to be predictable and laughable. The score by Michael Small tries to be as workable as possible, but it does not worked to be unforgettable. The editing has been elaborated to be acceptable but the using of some footage, from the first Jaws make the narration of the story pointless by distracting the audience. The cast like Lorraine Gary and Michael Caine did well with their performances, but it would entertain not as much as necessary to make a good movie. Jaws: The Revenge is one of the worst movies of all time.

How do I describe the use of a license that scared us witless and kept us out of the water? Jaws 1 was a classic. Jaws 2 was an ok movie. Jaws 3D (remember at the movies it was 3D, glasses and all) was bad except for the 3D effects (and Bess Armstrong, I had a crush on her, always had a thing for short perky blonds). Logic tells me this was going to be trash. So I had to see it, just to prove it was what I thought it was going to be. You need to double bag this baby and tie the twist tie in a knot for good measure.

Sheriff is dead (O no, not Roy, please don't tell me they killed Roy) but please believe Mrs. Brody is going to come to the rescue. (Hey Rocky, watch me pull a rabbit out the hat... o no not again,)

To sum it up, The Shark loses, again, even to this competition. But hey, thats Hollywood.

review_detailed_main: Like most horror movie sequels this is very scary. And like most horror movie is sequels it is underrated. It is no 2.8. I will tell you what is a 2.8. review_title: Great Parody- oh wait it's actually a proper movie
review_detailed_main:
OK where to start. The special effects are pretty damn terrible, actually they look worse than the first film made 12 years earlier, scientific accuracy was thrown out of the window (oh so a Shark can roar now) and the actors seem to have given up before the cameras started rolling.

If any movie defines flogging a dead horse then this is it. Most franchises do go down by films 3 or 4 but this just takes the biscuit. It's hardly surprising that no one's attempted a Jaws Film since, because this basically ripped the franchise apart, as though it had been attacked by a Great White

Lorraine Gary returns for the third (and hopefully final) sequel of the "Jaws" series that finds her getting some R&R in the Bahamas after the death of her son Sean at the hands (fins?) of yet another shark. Oh, and the shark FOLLOWS her to the fresh waters of the Bahamas, apparently holding a grudge for the last three sharks who met such grisly ends.

Jaws 3 was awful and this one is even worse. All parties involved come across badly starting with Emmy award winning director Joe Sargent and ending with actor Michael Caine (playing an Australian named Hogie - get it?) who couldn't accept his Oscar in person because he was making this turkey.

Some gorgeous scenery but otherwise none of it works. Numerous flashbacks only serve to remind the audience that "Jaws" was a great film.

Skip this movie and pick up a copy of the original.

review_title: I did not think it could get worse then part 3, I was wrong
review_detailed_main: Jaws Revenge tries to bring back the feelings from the original Jaws by bringing back the original actors and having the son be like his father, but it falls beyond short on every level. First of all, you cant have a proper jaws film without Roy Scheider, that man had passion, fear and bravery that he rippled into every scene. Secondly Jaws Revenge has next to no action. It's beyond boring as you follow the dull life of Mrs. Brody and her son. There is nearly no plot to the film as it drags on about nothing. For some reason almost no one dies in the movie. There is little to no suspense, as the shark barely does anything. Everything Michael does in the film makes no sense. The last part of the film is beyond bad as it literally makes no logical sense. And that scene with them in a pool with a painting as the background while they pretend to be in the ocean?? Cringe! The only pleasant thing about the movie was the filming of the crystal clear green water, the steady camera and the familiar cast. To sum up this movie in one word: Boring.

If you thought that the vengeful killer whale from Orca (1977) was exceptionally resourceful, wait until you get a load of the malevolent great white shark from Jaws IV: it follows Ellen Brody (widow of Chief Brody from the original film, who has since died of a heart attack i.e., Roy Scheider said "No!") all the way from Amity Island, Massachusetts, where it snacked on her youngest son Sean, to the Bahamas, where she has gone to stay with her remaining son, marine biologist Michael (Lance Guest), and his family.

Despite being told by Michael that sharks do not visit the Bahamas, Ellen (once again played by Lorraine Gary) is still afraid, her psychic powers warning her that the shark is nearby. Meanwhile Michael and best pal Jake (Mario Van Peebles) encounter the shark and attempt to study its behaviour, while pilot Hoagie (Michael Caine) tries to take Ellen's mind off all things finned and toothy by showing her the sights.

Even ignoring the ridiculous notion of a shark somehow tracking Ellen's flight south for 1200 miles, Jaws IV is still a really poor film, with none of the great characterisation, atmosphere, suspense or sheer horror of the original (hell, it doesn't even come close to Jaws 3-D). Way too much time is spent on Ellen's romance with Hoagie, Michael's relationship with his wife Carla (Karen Young), and his friendship with Jake, when it really should be focusing on the shark.

Even when it does get to the man-eating fish, the film is a complete let down, the rubbery shark completely unconvincing and not nearly deadly enough: only two people are killed throughout the entire film, Jake and Hoagie surviving their close encounters with the shark because it would be upsetting for the viewer if they died (they're too nice to get eaten). After plenty of silliness (including the shark pulling a plane under the surface of the ocean), the killer fish is stopped when Ellen rams it with the hull of Michael's boat, causing it and the vessel to explode.

3/10, purely for the banana boat scene, which delivers the kind of human chomping action that there really should have been more of.

This film killed off the Jaws trilogy, which is a shame as the first two were good. The plot started ok until somehow Michael had grown 4 foot since the last film. The next major floor was, how did a 20 ft shark (which growled like a lion) make it from the U.S. to the carribean. The dialogue was made up as the film progressed and the addition of Michael Caine to the film as the corney cross-eyed pilot 'Hoagie' just made the film mediocre. Jaws has finally been laid to rest after this feeble effort to reclaim some pride after the farce (later re-named Jaws 3-D) 1/10 ijh

I don't understand the negativity towards this movie. For the whole duration of the film I was waiting for the bad part to kick in.. everything about the film was good. The plot, the characters were aged correctly, the acting was good, there wasn't any awful 1980s CGI like there was in jaws 3. It kept me on the edge of my seat, it entertained me and It all correlated with the prior movies. People were irritated with Ellen's psychic connection with the shark which I also do not understand, it's a fantasy horror? No one has complained about movies like Chucky etc because it doesn't need to be realistic. I am very outnumbered with my opinion, but feel I should voice it. Definitely give the film a try and don't be put of by the negative reviews.

After losing her husband to the demonic great white shark known as Jaws, Ellen Brody loses her youngest son...before nearly losing her eldest son and granddaughter to the same shark.

Is it possible for a shark to be so vindictive that it is able to hunt down an entire family, no matter where they are in the world?

Well, no.

Unless you are in the Jaws cinematic universe that is!

Joseph Sargent directs this fuzzy sharked cheesefest, that takes us from straight from Amity to the Bahamas...with robotic shark in tow.

We follow Ellen, as she relocates to be with her sole remaining son- who works as an aquatic scientist, studying the migration of conch snails- and his family, for the holidays.

However, she is not the only one to head for warmer waters.

Because Jaws is not far behind, seemingly, on the hunt to finish off the family who did her dirty in the previous installations of the series.

The whole thing is part action film, and part psychological thriller.

With Sargent wasting no time getting into the action.

Sure...it might not be the most plausible story...but it certainly is a mighty entertaining film.

Despite the fact that, as a shark-bot, she has definitely seen better days.

If you don't like the plot...at least stick around for the sweetest performance ever, from the little girl who plays Ellen's granddaughter.

Cause she's an actual angel.

6 out of 10.

review_title: Ranks Right Up There with the Best of the Bad

review_detailed_main:
This film is truly mind blowing. Oh yes, there is certainly no denying that. Why? Well that's simple. Because it's the biggest piece of crap excuse for a film that I have ever seen!!! The whole plot (???) is contrived, the shark looks more fake than in the prequels, and as if SEA WORLD weren't an unlikely enough target (#3) now the target is anyone in the Brody family!!! This is NOT Jaws!!!

Jaws stands as one of the most memorable and excellent films of all time. And Jaws 2 is a great sequel. I refuse to count the last two films as part of the series at all. Actually, I like to pretend they were never made. Here are some things I really hated about this film:

1) Horrible directing- No one's gonna top Spielberg's astounding direction in the first film, but Jeannot Szwarc did a great job following it with Jaws 2. This film has some really awkward cuts, and it just doesn't feel right. The style is not as tense.

2) Fake attack scenes- In Jaws 1 and 2, attacks are barely shown if at all. There are sounds, splashing, and some blood. But in this film, we see graphic death scenes. Not only that, but the shark leaps from the water and somehow suspends itself in the air???

3) Shark looks MORE fake- You'd think that the animatronics would have improved from the earlier versions. Wrong. The shark in this version looks different and frankly much more unrealistic than in 1 and 2. It also GROWLS... Come on people! I am still baffled by how the effects of Jaws 1 and 2 were achieved, but this film just makes me laugh.

4) Plot???- I've already mentioned this, so I'll be brief... Uhhhh,no. Just, no.

5) The Music Sucked- Jaws 1 and 2 were both accompanied by the wonderful compositions of John Williams. Not only is the Jaws theme memorable, but the other music in the soundtrack fits in perfectly with the action. You don't see much, but you can certainly hear the tension in the music, which is scarier. This movie barely even uses the main theme, and when it does it's in the wrong spots. Sometimes in this film, there is no music at all when there should be some. And the music there is is all cliche and overdone.

6) Characters- Even without the incredibly stereotypical African-Americans in this movie, the annoying child, and the really unfunny Brit, this film has no sympathetic characters. I could really care less about the life of Ellen Brody. I could care less about Michael and his conk research. And frankly, if I were anyone in this movie I'd want to be Sean so I could get out of there as quickly as possible so as to avoid the rest of this horrible movie. Basically, this movie has the same character problem that Jaws 3-D had- No Roy Scheider. Come ON! Once the Chief was no longer in the picture, the story ends. Martin is Jaws, Jaws is Martin. Who cares about everyone else???

And last but not least....

7) Atrocious Climax/Ending- I don't even understand how this shark is supposed to have died. It went insane??? What is THAT??? He also got poked by a stick??? It was so incredibly stupid that I was just completely lost. And as if you couldn't tell how bad this ending was, just look to the fact that they had to rely on the climax of the FIRST film to make this one work! Actually, I'm glad they put this part in there. The best part of this movie isn't even from this movie. It's Roy Scheider's famous end scene from the first Jaws movie. Imagine that.

All in all, I would not recommend this film to anyone, ESPECIALLY not to anyone who's a fan of the true Jaws films. Stick with 1 and 2.

By far the worst film. And I'm not just talking about the Jaws films. This is the worst movie I've ever seen. The shark is so fake. And what is with the growling? Sharks don't growl! And the plot is stupid. A shark hunts the Brody family and to get away from it, Mrs. Brody goes to another beach. And how is it a shark can get all the way Caribbean in a few days. And what is with the flashbacks? Was she there when the first shark exploded? Also, a stick through the neck. At least in Jaws 3 they blew it up. Jaws: The Revenge is the worst movie of all time.

but it could Have Been a lot better if they had Read the book first and would have made a lot more scents I have this movie on VHS & DVD and still watch it occasionally

review_title: "Jaws" was never meant for a sequel!
review_detailed_main:
What could be more common than Hollywood making sequels to very successful movies? If it was successful and earned us money then a sequel must be made. In other words the aim is not so much to entertain as to make a quick buck! Jaws was simply not fit for a sequel. The shark dies in the first film. Bringing a new one along just to terrorize Amity once again is so stupid an idea that one wonders how did they come up with it, the weirdest part being that no resident of Amity seems to ask him/herself "why is it that great whites have a thing for our island?" Having Brody's wife assume that the shark came for them is so dumb, it actually insults our intelligence as an audience since we are supposed to buy that load of garbage.

The thing that struck me the most about the revenge is the final water sequence when they've killed the shark,(by driving a boat into it! Don't make me laugh) the horizon backdrop is obviously a painting. It's so obvious it physically hurts since even the water splashes against it! How are we supposed to not notice something that's literally thrown at our face. I'm sure most of you who've seen the film know exactly what I am talking about.

It seems that Universal has quite forgotten what constitutes a good sequel. Robert Shaw (Quint in the original Jaws) suggested that they make a movie about him on the Indian outpost in World War 2 (see his monologue in the first film) where a bunch of sharks ate many of his army buddies. This could have made a good sequel since it's unique and quite possible. But no! Universal had other plans. They'd rather show us a group of stupid kids trying to get away from a shark with Brody's son with them (of course, great whites never forget!)

In the revenge the studio has taken its overwhelming stupidity to the next level. A shark eats Helen Brody's son and then another shark hunts her and her second son in the Bahamas. As the poster says: This time it's personal. Indeed it is. The great white sent a message to his buddy in the Bahamas asking him to do some killing on his behalf and obviously he agrees. This friend of the great white is apparently some kind of X shark due to the fact that he is blessed with vocal cords that enable him to roar (maybe its mother mated with a lion) and has another extraordinary ability to stand on water. So he is an X super shark.

I can't believe I bought the damn DVD. But anyway it serves a completion purpose. I'd like to finish this article by making a film suggestion to Universal pictures and Hollywood. You seem to be so into making sequels and prequels e.g Saw3, The Texas chainsaw massacre:The beginning, why not make a 5th Jaws? "Jaws: The return of the great white", where the shark gets cloned by modern day technology and is then free to continue his hunt for the descendants of the Brody family. Sounds stupid? What do you care as long as it makes money we are all happy and we do't give a damn about quality.

review_title: Shark had no stomach for real meat.
"Sharks come and go, Ellen." Indeed they do.
review_detailed_main: If you've seen Jaws' Revenge, you're probably wondering where my review is. Well, Bam. Anywho, Jaws and the Revenge is the story of a shark who swims around looking for people named Brody. Oscar winner Adrien Brody, rocking guitarist Brody Dalle, ostensibly foreign pro wrestler Bruiser Brody, if your name is Brody, the shark would like to have a quick this-and-that with you. Ellen Brody is a mother who lives on Amity Island and after losing a husband to post-traumatic disorder after killing not one but two of the these buggers, and seeing her son turn into Dennis Quaid for the last movie, is letting her young son work in law enforcement. Her only caveat is that he only go close enough to the water where the shark can lunge (and baby, the shark in this movie got some moves!) and chew his arms off. The shark does, but then the son leans forward to yell at it. The shark then eats the rest of the son. Ellen has had enough of this and moves with her surviving son, who is no longer Dennis Quaid, to the Bahamas. The shark decides that's cool with him, and he swims down there before they can get there in their plane. Not exactly a fast plane, there. Upon arriving we meet the rest of the cast. There's Lenny, played Jamaicanly by Mario Van Peebles, who you may recall from his other work, unless you've never heard of him. And of course Chewie, played by Michael Caine, who like Louis Gossett Jr before him, used winning an Academy Award as a stepping stone to get involved with this franchise. (Look it up). How Jaws got Revenge is about the mind of a killing machine, who swims, eats, and gets revenge. Ellen takes things into her own hands and drives a boat to find this shark. Peebles' character is grabbed by the shark and dragged under water. Don't worry kids, he's totally fine though. This shark is aggressive though. He roars, bellows, moos, coughs, and growls. Chewie is very attracted to Ellen Brody, who after four movies of this would probably like to change her name from Brody. Chewie, in a role that would establish Michael Caine as a legend, is insatiable in his quest for her. He roars, bellows, moos, coughs, and growls. At the end of the day, The Revenge of Jaws will keep you on the edge of your seat, white-knuckled, biting your lip, making you wonder what will happen next. After seeing this film you will know what the words "revenge" and "personal" truly, truly mean. And knowledge, unlike sharks, is something that will never just come and go. RRRRRROOOOOOOOOAAAAAAAARRRRRR!!!!

review_title: Is it possible to give a movie a 0 rating?
review_detailed_main:
This is one of those movies that convinces you that studio heads really don't know what they are doing, that it's all a big crapshoot. It's hard to believe that someone looked at the treatment for Jaws 4 and said, "Yeah, this is a good idea. Let's go with this."

A real head-shaker.

review_title: This is what they mean by "so bad it's good".

review_detailed_main:
Yes. This movie was bad. BUT, it was not the worst. 'Jaws' movie, that is. But seriously folks, where did they find this script? A million chimpanzee's randomly banging away on typewriters could come up with a better concept. This was a bad, bad movie, and I even heard it lost money. (Ha ha, there is justice). There were two redeeming qualities, though, the first was that it was not Jaws 3(D), and the second was the music, was was better than Jaws 3(D!). And when I write that, I mean that it could be actually good (whoa, the music, I mean) and that the rest of the time, it wasn't so bad that it made me want to tear off my ears.

But enough praise for this piece of cheese. The 'story' was basically this: a giant sock-puppet shark plans to hunt down the remaining members of the family from the original Jaws and kill them in a series of incoherent jump cuts. But the mother, being the astute little one, comes to the conclusion that the shark is seeking revenge for the other four sharks that the Brody's killed through-out the other movies. So she logically goes with the LAST STARFIGHTER to an even smaller island in the Caribean populated by a bunch of 'Jamacians' and Michael Caine.

There is some romantic banter between Caine and the widowed Lorraine Gary (the mom), and we get to see the LAST STARFIGHTER and his good friend (snicker) Mario Van Peebles put tracking devices on conchs.(?)Though out all the remaining running time, only one person gets killed, and, I would like to note, that person was driving a Bannana Boat....

I won't give away the ending, although I will say that Gary (Lorraine) steals a boat to kill the shark, Michael Caine's seaplane gets eaten by the shark (?), Mario Van Peebles get munched and dragged underwater but...doesn't..die, THE LAST STARFIGHTER's huge scientific ability as he try's to fix the weird shark-zapper thing by lightly tapping the outer-case. And, oh yeah, the shark roars repeatedly, jumps 20 feet out of the water, stays there for about 30 seconds, gets impaled on the boat, and blows up.

Whoops.

While enjoying this movie, its fun to try and find bloopers and technical mistakes. For instance, whenever the shark appears, there is always a pool of blood, even if it hadn't attacked anything. Also look for the pole that propels it attached to its side in practically every shot (or the rail attached to the bottom as it stalks the corridors of the sunken ship(?)) There are also fun little tidbits and factual errors such as the fact that sharks don't roar like lions, and even though they can in fact jump out of the water, they tend not to stay there for half a minute. They also try to avoid traveling hundreds of miles in a single day, and usually, they arn't fixated on the death of a single family.

I could go on forever complaining, but I already have. I recommend watching this if you have insomnia or if you have no choice.

that's what this movie is. Acting is awful from everyone involved. Lorraine Gary looks pathetic as grandma heroine. Shark looks faker than ever. That Michael guy with his jamaican friend isn't too bad. Michael Caine is totally spoiled. The ending is the worst part, the shark just gets poked by a stick and blows up, along with the whole ship. Pathetic. Director Joe Sargent tries to cheer us up with some footage from the original movie. He must've realised he screwed the movie up totally by the time he shows us Martin Brody shooting the shark. I mean, how much lower can you sink as a director?

review_title: It's really not that bad. Having said that I do have some thought

review_detailed_main: I wouldn't necessarily say that this was a bad film. In my opinion, it was nowhere near as bad as Jaws 3. I'm no expert on Oceanography, but a lot of the scientific aspects of the film seem very...off. Not to mention the fact that the sharks life comes to an abrupt end, that doesn't really seem physically possible when you think about it. I really think the Jaws films sort of took a nose dive after the second film. Though I still stand by my statement when I say that Jaws 3 was still my least favorite. One scene in this film shows very clearly that while they were in the plane, the effects were added in afterwards, meaning they probably weren't even in a plane at all and probably just the front half of one, with video shot from inside a real plane put in the background, though honestly, this was not the first time someone did that in a film.

review_title: Easily the weakest of the franchise
review_detailed_main: Jaws- The Revenge is simply a disappointment. Containing what is perhaps the most slipshod storyline I've ever seen in a horror movie, the movie is critically flawed in so many areas that I don't even know where to start. First of all the very concept of a shark seeking revenge on somebody is completely ludicrous. The special effects are a thorough joke. My guess is the makers were trying to show the detractors of the first Jaws movie how a badly designed shark REALLY looked like. As for the performances- don't even get me started. This is a complete mess of a film. Fans of the Jaws movie should keep their distance from rubbish like this. I can't believe I'm saying this but- watch Jaws 3-D instead!

My Take: Incredibly awful sequel to the incredibly terrific classic.

(This is an extended version of the review I wrote on February 2007)

Has it come to this? How did a classic film end up a big rolling turd after a few years time? We all know JAWS: THE REVENGE is bad, but it's made worse by the fact that it was a spawn of a masterpiece. It's hard to mention Steven Spielberg's JAWS right next to this awful insult of a sequel, even for simple sequel-sake. This is just bad.

I liked watching the original "Jaws", the first two sequels were fine, but when it comes to "Jaws:The Revenge", things change. This film is obviously trying so hard to be, not like to be, the original. The film tries to turn Lorraine Gary as a fighter, turning her into something like Sigourney Weaver in 'Aliens", which is simply silly. She obviously allowed herself to be sucked into the role, and she even tries hard to be Ellen Brody's Husband Martin, like saying his lines before shooting the shark("Smile you son of a B#@*h!!!").

The plot involves Ellen Brody's (Gary) attempt to avenge the death of her son's death. Fair enough, only director Joseph Sargent wants us to suck in as much lame-brained silliness and pass them up as willing suspension-of-disbelief. Just how much stupidity can this viewer take while watching this film? Well, once the real plot unfolds, I'm already losing track of the numerous moments of stupidity. I think I just found a film that reaches new heights of incompetence.

Camp is probably one reason to see this, but as yourself: Do you really want to spend money of something you desperately want to laugh at but have to endure 89 minutes (that's long enough!) of tedium and insulting stupidity? Funny, in one scene, Mario van Peebles' (in a ridiculous Jamaican accent) says to some of the characters "If mediocrity were fat, you'd all be whales!". It's easy to say this to anyone involved in this mess.

Rating: * out of 5.

review_title: Utter Disgrace. Ridiculously plotted and badly made

review_detailed_main: Jaws the Revenge is stupid and it looks cheap, but it has the best pacing and even given it's low budget, it has some of the most thrills - the sunken ship sequence for instance. The acting is top draw (better than Jaws III) and the direction is nice and tight. The music score is really creepy too. It's highly fun but totally unbelievable. I love it.

review_title: What the hell is going on here.
review_detailed_main:
This is probably my nomination as the worst example of film making I've ever seen. Sure, there are more worse movies, but they may not have had the advantage of a budget or the backing of a major studio, OR of being a "Jaws" for that matter. This is a travesty from start to finish. The movie should have been titled "Jaws, The Quest To Be Eaten". Every character seems to go out of their way to literally throw themselves in the path of the shark. Correct that, "character" is the wrong word. Caricature is the term. Also, even "shark" is inadequate to describe our wee beastie of nature. Supersonic shark is the more correct description as "Bruce IV" manages to swim half the length of a continent in three days. He also, honest to god, roars. Yes, roars. Sure, whatever. The plot is a meandering mess, establishing certain story and character development points, only to completely forget about them when the next scene roles around. Though it's not like you particularly care about any body anyway. The acting would embarrass Anson Williams. Again, it's easy to pick on the likes of Lorraine Gary or Lance Guest. They are obviously not real actors and are merely taking a paycheck. If they themselves think they can act, well, delusions delusions. It is Michael (pay me! pay me!) Caine and Mario (I'm not a stereotype!) Van Peeples that should know better.

This movie makes "Yor: Hunter From the Future" look like a taut, masterfully crafted artistic triumph. nuff said.

I think there must have been a deleted scene where the shark is hiding in the airport with dark glasses and a trench coat to determine where the family was heading, if not the big bugger must have tapped the phones.

I'd note a spoiler alert but this little gem is spoiled the second you start it, it's pre spoiled. If they make a "Jaws the 13th" it should begin with a global network of great whites on a conference call plotting an attack on the Brody family on their planned vacation to Kansas.

Up off your stool Lorraine, one more round!

Simeone thinks it's an horrible movie but all the scenes and the animatronic quality makes me thinking that the worst Is Jaws 3... Remember that in Jaws 3 there was some errors like the Shark swimming backwards. I enjoyed this movie, good work...

I've commented on all the other Jaws films so I thought I might as well comment on this one, the final (we hope) one. This one is even worse than part three and that one was awful. This one is an insult to the viewer and a kick in the teeth to the people that made the original classic Jaws film. A pity Spielberg couldn't have blocked all these Jaws sequels from getting made, I mean there isn't an E.T IV out there is there? Michael Caine despite being a terrific actor is no stranger to bad films but Jaws: The Revenge has to be the worst of the lot, yes even worse than The Swarm. The storyline here is awful, the special effects are dreadful and the actors look like they know they are starring in a pitiful movie. Avoid this movie, watch the original again or even Jaws 2 which is acceptable enough. Jaws 3D and The Revenge should be deleted forever.

review_title: The worst mainstream film ever made.
review_detailed_main:
Why do they keep showing this film on that AMC channel? Who could possibly consider this a classic? The film is so bad that this is my second time pummeling it with an angry review.

Jaws: The Revenge is in fact the worst mainstream film I have ever seen, and I've seen 'em all. The cast is good enough but completely wasted by an awful script, bad direction, and anything else that can make a movie bad.

The story centers around a great white shark apparently seeking the Brody family out to get some revenge for all the others which have died in these films. Maybe it's just some kind of ghost that continues to haunt the Brodys. Anyway the films begins with some murky shots of the bottom of the harbor near the coastal resort town where the family has always lived. The camera work is nothing special, then the audience is hit over the head with some laughably unintelligible narration about fate and whatnot.

The first shark attack claims young Sean Brody who is following in his late father's footsteps as a local cop. The grief-stricken mother then heads to the Bahamas to spend the Xmas holiday with her other son Mike and his family. You see, great whites don't like warm water, and there has never been one seen there before! So naturally, our shark would not dream of turning up to spoil their Xmas, would it? The film is terrible in many, many ways. Let's look at some of them...

The shark is poorly constructed, and looks very fake. At times you can see the mechanical devices holding it up and making it move. The shark seems to float very slowly and almost on its side most of the time. When angry, this shark even has the ability to roar and growl.

The editing is seriously flawed, as well. In one scene, Mike Brody and his partner Jake (Mario Van Peebles) are talking about how "the money is gone... the shark's gone... can't track it." That would be fine and dandy if only for the fact that these two clowns don't even see the shark for the first time until the NEXT SCENE!!!! What the hell?? How could have this slipped past the editor? The dialog is putrid and forced. Mario Van Peebles ad-libbed all of his lines, and it shows. Nobody has anything either important or interesting to say about anything. Even Michael Caine is hard to stand, and he has always been a very likable actor.

The film has very little action. Huge gaps of dead spots buffer the shark attacks. There are flashback sequences had by people who were never there to see the incidents take place. The final showdown between Mrs. Brody and the shark is ridiculous from any standpoint. It defies logic, physics, and common sense all at once.

What do you suppose the studio bosses at Universal said after they first saw this stinker? What could you say? This film has been criticized by everyone under the sun for the past 18 years, and deservedly so. It truly is the worst film ever released by a major studio.

a very generous 1 of 10 stars from the Hound.

review_title: One of the Worst Movies Ever Made. Truly Terrible
review_detailed_main: Michael Caine needed a new house and Jaws The Revenge paid for it. I hope he was paid well to be in this mess. The acting, directing, script, and visual effects are beyond terrible. The story is stupid and the title is absurd. The movie is never exciting nor scary. The Shark is laughable and looks cheesy in every scene. The movie is not worthy of the name Jaws. Jaws 3D was a bad movie but next to this junk it looks decent. The Shark gets the revenge on the moviegoer by delivering a sequel so bad that it insures no further Jaws Movies or Movie Sharks will die. Jaws was the first great Blockbuster and Jaws : The Revenge the great movie franchise mega-bomb. The director and screenwriter should never work again after this incompetent mess. The horrible film is regarded by many to be one of the worst films of all-time. It is the second worst movie of the 1980's after Garbage Pail Kids the Movie. 1/10 Truly Terrible.

This franchise just makes no sense. You'd think that after the events of the first two, none of the Brody's would ever want to go near water ever again. But then you have that 3D thing and they're working at Sea World, and here there's some Brody thinking a trip to Barbados would be a good idea. Never mind that some shark kills yet another Brody in one of the opening scenes, to the ocean they go! Are we really supposed to feel sorry for her when she gets into trouble? The great white and his trusty propeller soon find her, and then he kills some people that really have nothing to do with anything. We're led to believe that he's just after the Brody family, but the makers can't kill of any more of them so they just have him eat a couple of nameless characters with zero lines. Exciting times. Michael Caine appears for some reason, and he really just enjoys his free vacation and pads out the running time by playing the standard love interest. He brings in some class, which this movie is just seriously undeserving of. I know it had to be cheaply made, but that's no reason to deliver something this bad.

review_title: Really bad movie, would not recommend
review_detailed_main: The first Jaws was brilliant, second- wasn't as good, third- getting bad, Jaws The Revenge- absolutely ridiculous! If your thinking about buying the DVD - don't waste your money. The CGI effects are rubbish, like drawings. As for the acting, it was appalling. I feel sorry for the actors who starred in such a low budget film! How can it be part of the Jaws movie franchise - it's not Jaws material at all! A real disappointment for the movies Steven Spielberg started off so well. Whoever directed this movie wants sacking! DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE UNLESS YOU FEEL LIKE A LAUGH! DON'T BUY THIS MOVIE! I DON'T RECOMMEND IT AT ALL!!!

review_title: Ladies and Gentlemen , The worst movie ever made
So end the "Jaws" series, which shouldn't have been a series in the first place
review_detailed_main:
"Jaws The Revenge" concludes the series about a shark attacking Amity Island. This time, the shark apparently knows about the Brodys, so he's out on revenge (hence the title). Ellen Brody knows of this and tries to get her oldest son to quit his job as a marine biologist.

Overall, this movie was just god-awful. Now, "Jaws" shouldn't have been made into a film series, but money has persuasive ways. The writing was absolutely awful, I really felt that it should have been called "Jaws: The Mediocrity," or "Jaws: The Voice of Reason: Don't make anymore 'Jaws' movies," or maybe even "Jaws: The End." Don't see this. It's the right thing to do.

I believe that everyone who laughs at Jaws:The Revenge has a secret obsession for it. They really do find it to be the best Jaws movie. This is because Jaws The Revenge IS the greatest of all the Jaws movies.It has the best performances, the best photography, the best soundtrack and it has the best actor- Michael Caine. People who hate this movie do not hate it really.They love it more than the original yet refuse to acknowledge it publicly. Michael Caine excels in his role as a travel weary pilot, trying to find a reason to live and finding it in Lorraine Gary. Thus follows a tale of two lonely people trying to find company in their later years. Beautiful. True, the shark follows Lorraine Gary to the Bahamas, but so what? Have you never been followed by a wild animal on your way home from the supermarket? I was once followed by a cat. I went on holiday to Austria and on opening my chalet door, there it was, purring for meat. The cat had followed me abroad. These things can happen. Great movie.

review_title: Honestly, the second best of the "Jaws" series.
review_detailed_main:
This movie doesn't receive much love but I think it really deserves some. It's understandable why this movie is regarded as a bad one. It's the third establishment in a series of unneeded "Jaws" sequels. Both 2 and 3 were disappointing movies, especially compared to the first of course so how could the third sequel be possibly any better? It's easy to bash a movie like this but I'm not going with the majority here on this one.

I'll explain why I feel that this is the second best movie from the "Jaws" series. Despite the previous two sequels it actually tries to recapture the atmosphere of the first movie. Also of course the fact that Lorraine Gary reprises her role as Ellen Brody adds to this feeling and atmosphere. The movie has lots of returning character and references to the first "Jaws" movie, something that the previous two sequels mostly ignored. This movie is actually the closest to the first "Jaws" movie in its atmosphere, story and tension. The only reason why this movie is not as good as the first "Jaws" movie is the fact that it hasn't got the characters Quint, Chief Brody and Hooper in it. Also of course Spielbergs skill and subtle touch is missing and so is John Williams' musical score.

The use of some archive footage from the first "Jaws" movie, in some flashbacks scenes might be a bit cheap but in my opinion it works effective. It perfectly binds the first and last establishment of the "Jaws" series. It also explains the 'lame' story better. The story is that a shark wants to take revenge on all the Brody's. It's of course incredibly silly that a shark would ever do such a thing but a story like this was necessary to put an end to the "Jaws" series. After this vengeful shark would die, it would be highly unbelievable that any of the Brody's would have a later encounter with a great white. This sort of story was simply needed to put an end to the series and for me it's really satisfying.

It is a really great and enjoyable monster movie. It has some well build up and executed sequences and an ending that also doesn't disappoint. In my opinion it's a great way to end the "Jaws" series, even though my opinion still is that none of the "Jaws" sequels should had ever been made because they are simply pointless.

7/10
