review_title: what a waste of time and money
review_detailed_main: OK OK OK..... this was probably one of the worst films that i have ever seen in my entire life!! i mean.. the the first jaws was AWESOME, the 2nd jaws was good, the third jaws was very very very bad and had very very poor special effects, and this movie was a waste of time and money. the money people spent on this movie could have gone into a movie that would actually be worth watching. i only saw part of this movie and i had to change the channel because i was getting very very bored because there was no real good scenes that were making you get off of your seat and scream cause you wanted the person that being chased by the shark to get back out of the water so they wouldn't get eaten, there were none of those scenes in this movie and that made me made because there were a whole bunch of better channels that i could have been watching that day.

I find it difficult to believe that this was supposed to be a serious Jaws film, and have come to the conclusion after seeing it again on daytime telly recently that it must have been made bad on purpose

Some of the dialogue is just brilliant, at the very end of the movie Brody's wife says some parting words to her son.. 'Are you going to be okay?' he nods and she says..... 'Okay'. brill!

Michael Caine has some of the best lines, such as the classic.. 'Oh Sh^t!' when his plane gets attacked by Jaws. and the profound 'There's a lot of ocean out there'

The sound in this film is comical, at the end of the movie for some bizarre reason we have inaudible dialogue going on from Michael Caine as the plane pulls away. This technique is used elsewhere also when a car pulls in.. inaudible dialogue suddenly becoming clear as Caine opens the car door! Very stylish sound design!

In my view this movie must have been made bad on purpose, maybe originally designed to be a comic take on Jaws that never quite made it. Anyway it makes for some light entertainment, and Caine looks very happy throughout with the pay cheque he undoubtedly picked up for the project!!

You won't find the late great Roy Scheider reprising his famous role as Chief Brody in this installment but his wife Ellen Brody(Lorraine Gary) still lives in the island resort town of Amity, Sean is now a deputy in Amity. during the Christmas season, Sean is called to untangle a log from a buoy, and when Sean goes to the buoy, he's killed by the eponymous great white shark that scene is actually a inspiring sequence that recalls the 'original and best Jaws opening attack scene) Mrs Martin Brody heads to the Bahama's with her family but uh-oh guess who's coming to dinner? believe it or not but the giant fake fish follows and this time it's personal! it's also unbelievable that Sir Michael Caine is in this giant turkey! legend has it's one of his famous roles for 'the money' which apparently has enabled him to build a house from the proceeds!

review_title: If onley i could give it 0/10....

review_detailed_main: I didn't even think this movie existed for the longest time. Surely after the farce that was Jaws 3D no one in their right minds would try to milk this concept any further, right? Wrong. Jaws 4 "The Revenge" is a jumbled mess of ideas that only a person on a raging coke binge would have thought as passable material. Are there any redeemable qualities to this movie? No. Michael Caine was the lone hope in this movie, and gets terrible lines and looks generally bored with whatever is going on. Lorraine Gary is in this movie because her husband owned the studio that produced it, and she comes across as a crazy widow who at this point should honestly be committed to a mental institute. The shark is shown very early and very often, and to call it laughable would be the understatement of the movie. It is amazing that I can't tell whether the terrible CGI shark in Jaws 3D or the terrible mechanical shark in "The Revenge" is worse. In the end, it doesn't matter. The story is incoherent and boring with very little tension or suspense. The characters are bland and forgettable while being played by actors who either took this movie too lightly or too seriously. The effects in this movie are something that a college student could come up with. No redeeming qualities in a movie that is a blatant cash cow. I wouldn't even call this a good movie to riff on, because it is just so boring.

This is one of the worst movies I have ever seen in my life.There is no comparsion to the original film.All these cheap sequels did was ruin the power of the orginal.Mrs Brody should have swam alone in 1975 at night!The trouble is everything.Jaws looks terrible.The screams.The horrible ending with the stick in the neck!!!!!!!!This film is what is wrong with lala land.They can never leave anything alone.This is same story with what was done to halloween.WHY CAN'T THEY LEAVE ANYTHING ALONE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

-10.00 is my score.
Sorry but I liked this film - sure it's got its flaws but I thought the actors did really well with it and it did a reasonably good job in continuing the franchise .

review_title: At least its better than Jaws 3 and a masterpiece compared with Shark In Venice!
review_detailed_main:
OK OK...Sharks don't take things personally. Sharks don't roar etc. BUT Sharks don't like eating humans so in the first hand Peter Benchley's best selling novel is not based on accurate facts. What i am trying to say? Movies are fiction hello? So ANYTHING can happen. I admit that the shark's personal quest for revenge is stupid even for a fictional movie universe, but at least makes the movie work because Jaws 3 was a total mess, and in my opinion is even worse than Jaws 4.

Now lets think about it. After the first movie (a true cinema masterpiece) everyone got the "jawsmania" and wanted to go to the theaters and watch the shark eating his victims. So the shark became the driving force behind the whole franchise (even they never planned to make it one). Bottom line we all watched the sequels for the shark and the shark delivers big time in this one. This movie its mindless fun and full of carnage.

In conclusion. The producers wanted the Brodys in the film, (this family with sharks is like John Mclane with terrorists), they had the shark and they needed to find a way to make the Brodys get in a situation against a shark again. Someone said to make it personal, and the others agreed! So what? At least is not Shark In Venice!. Sure the movie could been better but it's entertaining and a fun movie to watch with a couple of beers.

review_title: From one of the greatest films ever to this
Just when you thought it was safe to go back in the theater
is this jaws or Friday the 13th?
review_detailed_main: the worst sequel in history,a shark that plans revenge and holds a grudge against the Brody family.wow thats logic.Lorraine Gary and a few of the lesser known stars from jaws return in this really bad sequel. was this a tax write off?universal should be embarrassed by this one. I'm surprised they didn't stick a directed by Alan smithee in the credits. a good cast is wasted in this,especially great actor Micheal Caine. lance guest(last star fighter)and Karen young(FBI agent on TV"s sopranos) also star in this.oh and Mario van peeples i think this almost killed his career.i think the shark took pointers from Jason voorhees from the Friday the 13th movies.this was the last jaws film with good reason. it killed the franchise like batman and robin.i cant even say this is so bad its good,its so bad it hurts.jaws the revenge is just plain bad.

What I really despise about Jaws 4 is that it completely ignored the events that happened in Part 3 and chronologically set itself up after Part 2. I can't stand that in horror franchises, it's extremely lazy writing! Another aspect of the film that was completely absurd lies within the idea that the great white is out seeking revenge against the Brody family. Lastly, it mentioned that Chief Martin Brody died earlier from a heart attack caused by a great white. What a joke! No wonder why this film is constantly bashed and often seen on worse movie lists. This loss falls squarely on the director and writers.

The only redeeming aspect of The Revenge was scoring Michael Caine to be in it and bringing back Lorraine Gary but let's be honest the two of them couldn't save this film. Half the budget for this movie had to go to Caine or he just wanted to vacation in the Bahamas, maybe both. It was odd too seeing these two great cast members having to try and sell these really cheesy bad lines. The beginning of the film had a surprising twist, which is respectable since it took some stones to pull off but it was way too rushed. From there, a lot of flashback scenes were inserted, with laughable dialog and crappy shark effect scenes. The Revenge was a really poor attempt to create a meaningful Jaws movie and solidify the series, it might have ruined it for good.

review_title: You wish if this movie never existed
review_detailed_main: In my opinion, I've seen two good "Jaws" movies, then the third one came which I thought it was lame and now I've seen the fourth one that takes the cake for being the absolute worst of the franchise. Where do I begin? Well, I give you one thing about what is the plot of this ridiculous movie: another great white shark comes in, but instead of attacking more people it wants revenge on the Brody family. Wow! That has got to be one of the most stupidest and ridiculous plot that I've ever heard in my entire life. From the show "Siskel & Ebert," Roger Ebert asks Gene Siskel what shark is this? A brother? Cousin? Maybe a distant relative? I don't know, but this revenge plot really makes no sense at all; its hardly a revenge movie because the movie keeps focusing more on some parts that we don't care, and while the shark only pops in whatever it feels like it. If its not focusing well with the revenge plot, then just call it "Jaws 4." Also, the movie has many errors like Michael Caine's character coming out of the water while his clothes is almost completely dried off (thanks to Siskel & Ebert); then you have the shark that knows where to find our human characters from traveling the United States to the Bahamas, and last but not least, the shark roars like a lion. Sharks can't roar! Here is another thing, how is the shark able to reach out to eat people by what using its tippy toes or thinking that the shark is Mr. Fantastic? I blame how the movie was written by a bad screenplay. Even the movie is badly directed by Joseph Sargent who also produced this. Do both the writer and director know that sharks can't roar, and making some dumb excuses that the shark is being powered by the magic of voodoo? Heck, they made Martin Brody's wife Ellen who she thinks is Spider-Man that her sharky senses are tingling, and having these flashbacks that she wasn't there. Except where she witnesses her granddaughter who almost got killed by shark, and watching her late husband and son having their moment at a dinner table from the first one. The dialogue in this movie is really terrible like Ellen's granddaughter asking about Uncle Sean coming back. Uh...he just got killed by a shark, and can't come back. Such a dumb question that she brought up. I really hated that the filmmakers made Ellen saying that her husband died because not only a heart attack, but his fear of sharks. Lorraine Gary should've know about this, as she may have seen the first two movies where Martin was trying to be brave and strong to kill two sharks; she could've say no to say that line because its really insulting to Roy Scheider's character, but no the filmmakers want her to say it and just made everyone mad on how much we love Roy Scheider from the first two movies. I find it just as bad as making Megan Fox's character looked bad in the third "Transformers" movie, where she was replaced by a model that can't act. I don't think the acting in this movie is good, and I don't buy Lorraine Gary as the lead. She is no Ellen Ripley. By the way, I like to point out that when she sees her granddaughter almost get killed by a shark, she steals a boat or ship as we know that she can't take it anymore but here is one question: if she is going to steal a boat to find the shark, then why can't she bring any weapons to kill it? She is not well prepared onto anything. Heck, after Sean dies at the opening scene, some cop leaves Ellen her son's gun and never bothers to take it with her to kill the shark. Well Ellen, you are some hero. You know that? Some hero. I do feel sad for Michael Caine for doing this movie, and I think I'm sure that he regretted for not attending the Academy Awards for getting his Oscar on his work for "Hannah and Her Sisters." I never saw that movie, but I wish if he hadn't done this movie. The shark itself looks good on the first three movies (while the third movie made the shark cheap looking in 3D), but here its so darn fake looking. The effects in this movie are just as bad as the effects from "Superman IV: The Quest for Peace." This movie won the Razzie for Worst Visual Effect over the fourth "Superman" movie. The movie has two ending that were filmed: one the shark gets stabbed, and two it explodes for no reason while Michael Brody's friend survives. I don't care which ending I like best, because they both have bad effects and they're both lame. I do kind of like Caine's reaction of the shark before his plane got taken down. Oh, I also don't care for the music either. You wish if this movie never existed, but hey this is the last one and I am glad that its all over. I think the "Sharknado" movies are more entertaining than the last two "Jaws" sequels. I give "Jaws: The Revenge" a flat out zero. But I have to give it a one, because giving it a zero won't make its 2.8 rating go down. I wish I could, but got to be respectful to IMDb's rating system; and seriously, this movie sucks!

review_title: Hey, Jaws, spit your guts out!
review_detailed_main:
What the hell happened in this series? I know that after Steven Spielberg and his magic wand of the original film left for better projects, the "Jaws" saga started falling down the cliff where each sequel gets worse by the number. Jaws 3-D? What the hell was that? The special effects were so faked that I bet those who saw that film just walked out when the special glasses didn't work. Why do we need more sequels to films that should've been left alone in the first place? Somehow there's a disease with the Brody family where sharks just keep to be coming by the numbers and bothering this poor family. Roy Schinder is not in this sequel but is seen through flashbacks from his wife (Lorraine Gray in her final film) after the family's young son Sean (Mitchell Anderson) gets his arm ripped off before being devoured by a new menacing shark. The remaining son Michael (Lance Guest) is in Jamaica working in oceans and studying the effects of fish while seeing that his mother comes to visit after the death of Sean where that pesky shark keeps returning. Is there a radar on the Brody family? Other stars include Mario Van Peebles in a Jamaican accent and Michael Caine who skipped his Oscar win for Hannah and her Sisters to do this hunk of junk.

AHHHHH!!!!

review_title: Michael Caine gets a paid trip to the Caribbean
review_detailed_main: I read an interview with Michael Caine once on how he selects which films to appear. If I remember right, he one looks that whether the role is different from what he last played and two he looks at where the movie was being filmed. I'm guessing he chose to appear in "Jaws: The Revenge" because of latter for it's warm Caribbean setting. How could there be any pretense that this was going to be a good movie when the poster tag line is, "This time it's personal." How is a shark going to take things personally from the prior three films? And when the shark got killed in all of the prior films, is this film's shark supposed to be the third cousin twice removed coming to get revenge on Chief Brody's wife (the only person from the original film appearing in this fourth installment). There is no reason to watch this film outside of put camp. It's awful and is only watchable when the mechanical shark appears.

review_title: Sharks don't jump on boats, or drag helicopters down either...

review_detailed_main: As a fan of the "Jaws" movies I was excited to see this one come along after the dreadful "Jaws 3D". It was going to be based back in Amity, stars one of the original actors and technology had made strides since the 3rd in the series. I was dead wrong on all accounts. Not only was this the worst in the series, it may well be the worst movie ever made. It starts off promising but deteriorates quickly. The tip of the dorsal fin on the shark actually breaks off in one scene (slow motion too!). It's boring, the acting horrendous and Ellen Brody's bi-level hair-don't is ghastly. I would rather drink a gallon of Ex Lax than sit through this crap again.

One of the most underrated films of all time. Thank you Mr. BoJangles for casting Michael Cain who pulled Mrs. Brody out of her depression to start her life over. Special effects were fantastic!! Most importantly, this film goes great with a cheese sandwich and a bag of Doritos. When the shark goes after the sexy blonde wife, pull out a pint of Ben & Jerry's Cherry Garcia to bring you to total movie eroticism.

I've seen this classic 142 times and I feel I'm a better woman for doing so. Sometimes when I'm doing the laundry I watch it while snacking on low sodium Ritz crackers. But other times, I eat a small box of Otter Pops which are like a Popsicle in a tube.

2.9? Okay, I know this film is the weakest of the franchise, but it doesn't deserve a rating THIS low. I gave it 7 out of 10 stars, at least. The shark may look fake at times, but were any of the sharks in this franchise even remotely realistic? And, don't even get me started on the "sharks don't roar" argument. Each film in this franchise depicts a shark either roaring or growling. So don't single out this film with that "logic" while ignoring the rest of them. You want real sharks? Go watch a documentary about them! These films are meant to be entertaining, not to be thought of as real.

review_title: Easily the worst in the series
review_detailed_main:
If you though "Jaws 3" was bad, you've seen nothing yet. "Jaws: The Revenge" is worse. And I mean a lot worse. This is one of the most poorly made and badly acted movies that I have ever seen. Joseph Sargent, the director of this trash, is a good director. He has directed lots of movies mostly on TV. He's won a couple of Emmy Awards to prove it. But what on earth was he thinking of when he made this. Certainly he got no help with the script. The screenplay is by Michael de Guzman. How can somebody write a script that is so incredibly stupid? The plot of "Jaws: The Revenge" is such an incomprehensible mess that it has to be seen to be disbelieved. And what about that acting? It was a travesty to see Michael Caine in this movie and watch him waste his considerable talents. And what was even more shocking is that when he won his first Oscar for Woody Allen's "Hannah and her Sisters" in 1987, he didn't show up on Oscar night to collect his award; he was making "Jaws: The Revenge"! Lorraine Gary (reprising her role from the first two "Jaws" movies as Ellen Brody), Lance Guest, Karen Young, Mario Van Peebles, and (the late) Judith Barsi all give bad performances thanks largely in part to the hilariously awful script. An easily seen continuity error late in the film proves that "Jaws: The Revenge" is as ineptly made as everybody has said. Oh, I forgot to mention the performance of Bruce the Shark. Whoever made that shark didn't even try to make it look real and convincing. The shark ended up looking fake and unrealistic. And as a result, of all these bad qualities help to sink "Jaws: The Revenge". And boy does it sink fast. Only the beautiful Bahamas locations keep me from giving this catastrophe no stars.

1/2* (out of four)

Who's stupid idea was this then? And what was Michael Caine thinking -- it would be any good?

Get a member of the Brodie family, chuck a shark at them and fill in the rest yourself. Not in the same league as The Postman for terrible films, but not far off.

You didn't even have the fun of seeing how stupid your mate looked in those 3D glasses from Jaws:3D. Terrible, no more of these please.

The tagline for Jaws: The Revenge states, "this time it's personal." Really? I thought it was already personal after the second Jaws film was made and another shark attacked poor Amity Island again. If Jaws: The Revenge should be seen as anything personal it should be viewed as a personal attack - better yet, an assault - on a tremendous horror film that capitalized off of suspense and editing.

I should've reviewed Jaws: The Revenge three weeks ago, but I've been putting it off because I've needed to review other films since then. And also, what can be said about Jaws: The Revenge that hasn't already been reiterated and restated time and time again? The film is a dreary slog that consists of waiting for suspense and atmosphere to build, waiting for the shark to appear, being disgusted when the shark finally does appear, and then finally being greeted with the end credits, concluding the mess we just witnessed. If you still want to classify the film as a horror film, even though I'd argue the series thrust its way into the action genre after the second film, then this is one of the worst, most redundant horror films I have yet to see.

The film stars Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary), whose husband Martin from previous films has died of a heart attack, which is believed to be brought on from the stress of dealing with sharks in Amity Island. Ellen now lives with her son Sean (Mitchell Anderson), who is sheriff deputy, and his fiancée Tiffany (Mary Smith). Despite normality seemingly coming back for the gang, Ellen is convinced she is being followed by a great white shark when she vacations to the Bahamas to visit her eldest son Michael (Lance Guest). Now it's a matter of killing another shark before the shark can kill them.

It's no wonder Steven Spielberg had no interest in pursuing a sequel to his original Jaws film and had no involvement with any of the three sequels. I imagine he recognized that a "man vs. shark" is only really fresh the first time around and that doing the same thing film after film would begin to become monotonous and painfully familiar. Even if Jaws: The Revenge wasn't plagued with such lame acting, terrible effects work, and collectively sterile camera-work, it would be hard to convince us that a fourth movie about a group of people going after another shark would be something worth paying to see.

I recall when I watched Jaws 3 and got so tired with the characters and the plot that I just wanted to see a shark attack. Then I saw how painfully cheap and ridiculous the shark looked and kind of wanted more exposition. Then when I received more exposition I kind of just wanted the entire thing to end. The film was a muchness. Jaws: The Revenge suffers from the same form of monotony. One is constantly waiting for something to happen, then upon being rewarded, they wish they had never seen such a thing. For the purists who complain that the shark was clearly artificial in the original Jaws, I'd love to see how they responded to the shark in Jaws: The Revenge. I doubt there's enough howling in the world that could do justice to its artificiality and stunning banality.

Thus concludes the Jaws franchise for now, thankfully. This is one of the few franchises I know of (next to the contemporary Paranormal Activity series) that failed to have another "good" film after its first film, which, in both series' cases, was phenomenal. One should take the hint how in conversations about the original Jaws, rarely do the sequel names come up, and by God is that for the better.

Starring: Lorraine Gray, Mitchell Anderson, Mary Smith, and Lance Guest. Directed by: Joseph Sargent.

review_title: A really terrible shark film with a few bright spots within
review_detailed_main:
After the death of her son, a woman decides to go visit her other son in the Bahamas where everyone comes to believe that the killer shark that killed their family has arrived and is stalking the area forcing them to race to stop it from attacking the rest of the community.

There isn't a whole lot to like in this one. One of the few bright spots here is the action sequences when they occur as the few attacks the shark has aren't all that bad. The opening attack, where a victim is savagely ripped up and bitten savagely before being pulled underwater, is quite stunning and really shocking as it sets a great opening for the film, a later attack on a crowded beach where a victim is snagged off a marine toy in front of a small group of kids is really a great sequence for its cruelty and viciousness than anything else and the chase sequence in the sunken galleon does have an air of suspense as the shark does manage to constantly get at the victim after every possible method is used to put distance between them. Beyond these, though, there wasn't much to really like about it as there's a lot to really dislike in this one. The utmost flaw is that the film has the most unbelievable and nonsensical plots ever. Beyond the fact that sharks are incapable of living in the location chosen, the fact that it manages to get to there in a short amount of time is very hard to believe. There's also the family history of the sharks that the film brings up. Using the film, the shark is in fact the first film's third-cousin twice removed, and would have no motive to carry out the vengeance issued. That's assuming that the connection is correct, and if it isn't, then it's even more off in terms of where the shark falls in the family circle. The other big mistake in the film, beyond trying to figure out where the shark comes from, is the very slow pacing involved. Scenes drag on for far too long or have no reason to be there other than padding out the length. The biggest one is the family quarrels about being in the water, which was done nicely enough at first but then it happens twice in a half-hour span, and nothing comes of them since they all go into the water afterward. The struggling marriage scenes have no bearing on the plot and seem needlessly thrown in as well. There's a couple of other big problems in the film, the biggest of which is that the film feels really flat. In fact, the film flat out ignores all opportunities to create tension or fear. Just about all the attack scenes seem perfunctorily rushed and no effort is whatsoever made to make them frightening or even suspenseful. The ending, which should've been a big rousing affair to finish off the shark once and for all, plays out really flatly and the stupidity found within has a lot to do with that. Finally, the shark does look really fake, and there's really no scenes where it looks the slightest real. It simply floats along with minimal movement, being even more distracting. This really wasn't all that great.

Rated PG-13: Violence, Language and children in danger.

review_title: This movie is such an atrocity, i admire its guts.
review_detailed_main:
If i could put into words what a bad film this is, i should receive an Academy award. Its true, seldom does one come across a film so awful, that it actually inspires admiration for the people who made. Whoever they are however, i'm sure that they have long since been fired from the film industry. I might be a tad mean, but the gap in quality between Jaws and Jaws the Revenge is so massive, i don't think another one exists in the entire history of cinema. The one star a gave to this film is for the guts of the filmmakers to actually attempt putting such a lame, and utterly pathetic film on the film reel.

The only good aspect of this film is the music, although it variates on the classic John Williams tune, as it allows one to close their eyes while watching the film, and admire the music. But then there's the roaring shark (really, a roaring shark? you must be kidding? sharks don't roar!) Oh, they do, in this film apparently. Actually both the shark and anyone watching this film has something in common when it comes to jaws. the shark is using its jaws to chow people, while your jaws are hitting the floor. Oh yes, and did i mention that the shark also seeks revenge on the Brody (Sharks don't seek revenge! What are you talking about?) Yep, thats what makes this film truly unique. A shark, probably a second cousin 5000 times removed from the original Bruce. Apparently Matin Brody has died from a heart attack from "FEAR"! Like he new another Great White was coming to attack the town. Its like he had some sort of telepathic link with it. (That's impossible!) I know it is.

I don't think anyone enjoyed seeing young Sean Brody getting killed like that, especially considering that he is the little kid from JAWS, who everyone thought was so cute for imitating his father's movements like that. AND, you know what? The SHARK LAYS AN AMBUSH!!!!!!! Wow, i bet you'd never heard of that in the history of cinema. In fact this film is so bad, that almost every Jaws spinnoff is better than it, and that's just insulting.

Also, this film leaves Amity island and takes place in the Bahamas. Unless the shark flew, or hitched a ride on a speed boat, which is the only way it would have gotten there in time, this doesn't help the credibility of this picture. Oh, and for peaks sake, in the sharks death scene, they actually had the nerve to steal a shot of the original film. That i admire. That, and the whole roaring shark shark thing. Apart from that, the film has undeveloped characters, a crappy story, and is 87 minutes long, which is just unbearable for such junk. Oh, and just for the record, great white sharks cannot stop moving, or else they stop living. Someone should tell that to the films director.

Most of the problems with this film have been described already. One that I haven't seen is the continuity problem. In Jaws 3D, the Brody kids are contractors in Sea World. In this, one Brody kid is a Sheriff in Amnity, and the other is a Marine Biologist in the Bahamas. Also, he's about 10 years younger. Mind you, this is the least of the problems with this film (especially since you can't really tell that those guys in 3D are supposed to be the Brody kids just by watching the film.

review_title: Just when you thought it was safe to go back to the cinema...
review_detailed_main: Dear God. Dreadful. Awful. A dire film whose association with the 1975 classic only goes to emphasise how bad this really is. How did the plot synopsis get past studio executives: "Well this time the shark (forgetting that the previous three in the saga have been blown up, electrocuted etc and therefore would have no knowledge of the Brody family) targets Chief Brody's wife after killing her son. She flees in a plane to Bahama and the shark follows thereby leading to a showdown which not only defies belief but also treads on territory that even comedies would not dare to offer. What was Michael Caine thinking? He is so much better than this dross. Avoid like the plague. Rent the original.

I find it a quite disappointing that this movie was even made, but I guess you could say that about Jaws II and Jaws 3-D. Each sequel was worse than its predecessor, and Jaws: The Revenge does not disappoint in that regard.

By the end of this film, it unintentionally makes a complete mockery of the entire movie series. I'm specifically referring to the instance where Michael Caine's character almost in jest flips himself back on board of the fledging boat without so much as a scratch on him moments after being attacked by a gigantic white shark. I remember joking with my friends, saying: "What if the pilot of the crashed plane (Caine's character) miraculously survives and climbs back on board? Wouldn't that be hilarious?"

Well, it was hilarious, and so was the rest of this picture.

The acting is downright dreadful and the storyline is completely ridiculous. It's somewhat unsettling that a team of professionals called a meeting, sat down and approved a plot line that calls for a giant shark to miraculously come back to life (unexplained) and stalk the family of the man who tried to get rid of him in the original title. Are you kidding me? The first significant moment of the movie occurs when the youngest Brody son Sean -- who is now the Police Chief of Amity -- is attacked and killed by Jaws during the holidays. The sound of a choir caroling on the beach mutes his cries for help a mere yards from the shoreline.

Hmmm....

Anyway, the plot continues and the eldest Brody son, Michael, visits for the Holidays/funeral and convinces the now stricken Ellen Brody to visit him at his home in the Bahamas. Though originally reluctant, she agrees and the film shifts to the beautiful islands.

While there, Ellen begins to lose it, fearing that the shark that killed Sean and terrorized Amity 10 years prior is out for revenge, suggesting it followed her to the warm waters of the Bahamas (a place unfit for sharks) and will instantly chase down the entire family the moment they enter the salty sea waters. Michael thinks it's a crazy idea, but when his daughter is nearly killed by the shark, he begins to think his loony mother may be on to something.

The ridiculous climax takes place in the middle of the ocean when Ellen decides it would be a clever idea to confront the sea beast alone on her son's boat. Making a painfully long series of events short: Ellen, her new love interest Hoagie (the surviving pilot), Michael and his assistant survive the wrath of Jaws, joyfully cheering as they float aimlessly in the middle of the vast blue ocean after watching the shark explode into smithereens.

review_title: I'm sure a lot of audience members would like their revenge for this movie...
review_detailed_main:
We all knew it would come to this sooner or later. Jaws... is a masterpiece in horror movie making and is considered by many as one of Steven Spielberg's best (rightfully so). Jaws 2 is decent, flawed but saved by Roy Scheider's great performance. Jaws 3 is... a funny movie.

But then there is Jaws: The Revenge... Why was this movie made? Did they really expect us to go "Oh, that makes sense" at this egregious premise where a shark goes after Martin Brody's wife as revenge? This doesn't make any sense whatsoever considering the shark Martin hunted DIED. All right? He killed him. But considering we now have a shark which is so p'issed off it swims aaaaaaaaaall the way to Bahamas, that has to mean it's another shark who was informed one of his friends died and so now decides to go after Ellen. You might believe this is a joke, but it's not! This is what actually happened!

The acting is a joke. Lorraine Gary is decent for what she has to work with, but the rest? Not very good. I don't remember much about Michael Caine's performance (he probably tried, but the stupid script didn't give anyone good material to work with), but Mario Van Peebles... He was absolutely ABYSMAL! What was up with the hokey slang he had to speak all the time? He sounded like an idiot! Whenever Jake (that's his character's name) was on screen, I was either laughing or shamefully shaking my head.

The shark itself looks... weird. It's very different-looking from the other sharks, although mostly in a negative way. It has a really silly design and makes you chuckle rather than horrified. Christ, the shark in Jaws 3 was at least believable enough to make the movie work. What I'm seeing here though, is a plastic toy. Was the budget a nickel or something?

The worst sin though is how boring this movie is. There are several scenes where you hear these knuckledhead characters "talking" with each other and you are just waiting for it to END already. If you are gonna develop characters... GIVE US CHARACTERS WORTH DEVELOPING!

It's funny because it's so bad... but it's groan-inducing for the same reason. I wouldn't say I don't recommend this movie, but I only recommend it if you want to see something which at least almost is unintentionally funny. If you are looking for what resembles even just an OKAY installment in the Jaws franchise... you've got better shi't to do.

review_title: wafer thin premise,but much better than # 3
review_detailed_main: this is the fourth and final installment in the "Jaws" franchise.this movie is not as bad as the third one.in fact it is much better.the only problem with this movie is its wafer thin premise.you really have to suspend your belief for this one.not that you didn't need to for the third one,but this one takes it to another level entirely.if you can get around that,you might enjoy this movie.it goes back to the roots of the first two and utilizes what worked the first time.there's more action in this one,not really alt of suspense to speak of though.there is however,some humour,in the form of Michael Caine as Hoagie/an island pilot,among other things.Mario Van Peebles also provides some laughs as Jake,a graduate student working in the field of marine life study.this movie does have its slow spots,but it manges to pickup before becoming too tedious.overall,i'd have to give "Jaws:The Revenge" 6/10

review_title: The shark that roared ... no, I'm not kidding
review_detailed_main:
Usually when a "3D" sequel of a movie franchise appears it is a sure sign that it has been milked for all its worth, and the final, derivative, intelligence-insulting rehash of a well-worn formula has arrived. Tragically, this was not the case with "Jaws".

Just to highlight the remarkable capability of Hollywood's cinematic alchemists to turn gold into lead, I must hasten to remind the reader that the original "Jaws" was an excellent film that set a high standard for the horror genre. Spielberg's original (which I gave an IMDb score of 9/10) stands, with the original "Alien", as one of the exemplars of my #1 rule for horror films. Don't let the audience get a good look at the monster -- until it's too late! Who ever would have thought that a simple dorsal fin could be so scary? Who even knew what a dorsal fin was before they saw "Jaws"?

But back to the grim task at hand, "Jaws: The Revenge" flagrantly violates this rule. If you get to see the shark all the time (and it's easy to see how poorly constructed the "shark" is as another reviewer has pointed out) then it's not scary. At all. Once that happens, what's the point of making a horror movie?

Let's talk about the title -- "Jaws: The Revenge". They really, honestly, sincerely mean that. It's not one of those movies where the monster goes berserk and the body count soars with gruesome special effects galore. No, not that type of revenge. You know, the type of movie where a sleazy corporate lawyer talking too loudly on his cellphone wades a couple of feet into the water and then ... CHOMP! (And the whole audience cheers.) I could imagine enjoying a movie like that -- in the right mood.

But I did not enjoy "Jaws: The Revenge". At all. When they say "revenge" they mean that other, human type of revenge. The shark actually has a personal vendetta against some poor woman throughout the movie, then jumps out of the water and roars at her. Now there are just three problems that I have with that.

1. The shark has a personal vendetta against a human being.

2. The shark jumps out of the water.

3. The shark roars.

Maybe it's just me, but I have a great deal of difficulty believing that any fish would or could do such things. Maybe in an animated feature where the fish also talk to each other and sing songs. Tragically, this was not such a movie.

The last straw for me is the abuse of genuinely talented, famous movie stars in this picture. Tragically, Michael Caine, Lynn Whitfield, and Mario and Melvin Van Peebles were all tricked into appearing in "Jaws: The Revenge". That may be my biggest bad-movie pet peeve. A low-budget schlock-fest with no-name actors is one thing. I can almost forgive the makers of "Manos: Hands of Fate". (Almost.) But when a major Hollywood studio drags good actors we know and like through a festering pile of manure like "Jaws: The Revenge", I cannot forgive that. At all.

IMDb Score: 1 out of 10 (only because I can't give it a 0)

review_title: The basis for one of the funniest stand-up routines ever
review_detailed_main: The only reason to see this movie is so that you can fully appreciate comedian Richard Jeni's hilarious take on the experience of watching this horrible, horrible movie in a hotel room one night. We've all been there - sucked into a bad movie, staying up way too late to see how the movie comes out, refusing to admit that it's as bad as it appears to be, hoping beyond hope that there's some hook, or twist yet to be revealed that will vindicate the hour-and-a-half plus already invested in the movie. But...nope. It's bad. Just plain bad. Do yourself a favour and see Jeni's bit. As for the movie...yikes. Poor Michael Caine.

After being a keen fan of the first two, and thinking 3D was terrible. Nothing beats the outrageous storyline of the fourth. Although the shark looks the worst of all four, there is one scene (where he drags the woman from the yellow boat) which looks fairly realistic.

My advice is to watch it for sheer entertainment, but do not take the film seriously. The acting and dialogue is awful...I don't know how its possible to recall flashbacks that you haven't witnessed. The deaths are extremely tame, with cutting back to a fake shark's mouth. Finally the death of the shark seems very tame, the version i've seen is the edited version, with the unedited being slightly better. The studio have cut to old scenes from previous Jaws films to finish the film off.

review_title: The Most Ridiculous Plot in Movie History
review_detailed_main:
Jaws: The Revenge is an unwelcome addition to the franchise, a movie no one truly desired. Jaws 3-D seemed to put the nail in the coffin of the franchise, clearly displaying that the filmmakers had exhausted all possible routes. They were clearly out of ideas. Yet, Jaws: The Revenge exists, and without exaggeration, it has the most stupid movie plot I've ever seen.

The story revolves around Lorraine Brody, the widow of Chief Brody (played by Roy Scheider), who supposedly died of a shark-related, fear-induced heart attack. After her youngest son, Sean, falls victim to a shark attack on Amity Island, Lorraine relocates to the Bahamas with her remaining son, Michael, a marine biologist. Astonishingly, the same vengeful shark manages to pursue them all the way from New England to the Bahamas. Having known about the plot of this movie for years and even having just watched it, I still can't quite believe Jaws: The Revenge is real. It undeniably ranks among the worst films I have ever watched.

The initial shark attack, admittedly, represents the film's least terrible aspect. It embraces a gory, horror-like execution that momentarily provides a flicker of trashy entertainment. However, this fleeting sense of promise swiftly dissipates as the movie rapidly deteriorates. Jaws: The Revenge is remarkably short on action, instead prioritising a melodramatic romance between Lorraine and Hoagie, played by Michael Caine. However, I didn't care about these characters or their situations due to the atrocious script. Still, Caine is the film's best part, even if he is phoning it in.

The sporadic action sequences lack any tension or suspense, primarily because the shark is persistently visible, looking artificial and rubbery. One of the original film's greatest strengths lay in its sparing use of the shark's on-screen presence, a principle that Jaws: The Revenge blatantly disregards. It seems as though the creators of this film had never even laid eyes on the masterpiece that started it all.

My Rating:1/2 out of ****.

In 1975, A Masterpiece was made, it was called Jaws. In 1978, Jaws 2 came out, it was good but not great. In 1983, it was Jaws 3-D, it was a guilty pleasure. Together these 3 would have made an uneven but decent trilogy. But no Hollywood is greedy and came out with Jaws 4. This film is one of the worst films of all time. Even the worst Halloween sequel (Part 6) cant compare to this.

On the trivia area it is reported that the events in Jaws 3-D were ignored during the making of this film. I heard the filmmakers hated Jaws 3-D and ignored everything that happened. Jaws 3-D was not a great film at all, but most people would have to admit its better than this ridiculous piece of crap.

The Shark in the films are not realistic at all. The model in the first was barely passable. However, Spielberg used the less is more technique to achieve suspense. Not much of the shark was shown but there was a great deal of Suspense. The shark is shown way too much here and it is fake looking as hell. Joseph Sargents does a terrible job at achieving suspense, ok there is no suspense. He is not Spielberg.

The acting is horrible. Lorraine Gary overacts all the time. Michael Caine is wasted. Why is he in this film anyway? Mario Van Peebles is annoying.

The way the Shark is killed is ridiculous and doesnt make sense. There is no way Lorraine Gary could take on the Shark by herself. She is not Sigourney Weaver, she is an old hag. The movie is consistently lame, everything scene is drenched with lameness. The flashbacks of the first movie have no purpose, just to block off the fact that the screenwriter had no idea how to kill off the Shark. I am surprised there is no Jaws 5. The Shark is supposed to be invincible and yet it looks like if you kick him he'll die.

Yet for all that is terrrible about Jaws 4, the Ocean is beautiful looking. It looks great to swim in. Who cares about the Shark, check out the Ocean. The Carribean is beautiful. For those images I was able to give Jaws 4 half a star instead of zero.

I've only seen this film once, about 10 years ago, but I still recall feeling so let down after seeing this.

Lorraine Gary was fine as a supporting roll in the first two films, but she does not come close to saving this movie. Basically, yet another shark shows up at Amity, and the widowed Mrs.Brody is convinced this shark is out for revenge against the Brody family when her adult son (possibly the character that Quaid played in Jaws 3, I'm not sure) is devoured by the shark.

So she goes to the Caribbean. The shark follows.

Somehow, Michael Caine and Mario Van Peebles get involved and they set out to re-create the last half hour from the original Jaws. Even going so embarrassingly far as to provide "flashback" footage that none of those characters ever saw first hand!

Also known as Jaws 4, run away from this one no matter what it calls itself. Only rates at a two because it is ever so slightly more tolerable than "C.H.U.D. 2". Stay away!

review_title: Finally, a director who doesn't lose sight of the endpoint
review_detailed_main:
The Jaws franchise is - or should have been - the greatest cinematic hillbilly family feud of all time. Sadly, the three prequels were ruined by glory-seeking amateurs, so focused on their own little vanity project, that they forgot that their one job was to set us up for the main event. Sargent, soldiers on bravely, here; but, without the groundwork, it just seems too much of a reach.

Okay, joking aside, I won't try to sell you on this movie on its merits. It really doesn't have any. But, I will sell some of you on this movie. Firstly, it makes a great cheesey double bill with Bula Quo. Secondly, there is the been there, done that, got the T-shirt aspect - although, admittedly, not as good as a T-shirt that says "Nilbog Milk" on it. Thirdly, even if you decide not to watch it, just be glad it exists. Be glad it exists for the same reason why you're glad that the final two episodes of the Prisoner exist. Be glad it exists for the same reason you are glad that the finale of Game of Thrones exist. Be glad for the simple pleasure of knowing that there are people out there who are looking forward to watching it, and they have some high expectations. Just enjoy the schadenfreude of it all.

I knew I would convince you.

review_title: Premise is terrible but, execution is not bad
review_detailed_main:
Let me state the obvious to begin. The idea of a shark having a personal grudge against a certain family is crazy. How would the shark even know who is a Brody and who isn't? That being said, I enjoyed it a lot more than I expected. While the idea is silly, the actual story of some of the Brody family being scared that a shark is targeting them is preformed pretty well. The action scenes with the shark are so much better than the third movie and are not far behind the second. I enjoyed all the nods to the first movie and felt it was just enough without dwelling on the past. The ending is alright until you get to the moment of the shark's demise which really doesn't make sense. From what I understand the original ending made a lot more sense even though it's still far fetched.

I realize that few will probably agree with my opinion but, I don't think this movie deserves the low rating it has. It is no classic but, it's a decent enough movie if you get past cringing a little whenever the "the shark is out to get us" statements are made. I think it still ends the franchise a good note and I'm personally glad the it didn't end with train wreck that was Jaws 3. I didn't expect to enjoy this movie very much but, I was pleasantly surprised.

review_title: Don't you kind of wish the shark would just eat all of them
review_detailed_main:
Why do they waste celluloid doing these things? Jaws - Great, Jaws 2 - well OK, Jaws 3 - what the? and Jaws, The Revenge - OK enough is enough. What is Michael Caine doing in this piece of cr*p? Oh I forgot Michael actually enjoyed doing these silly flicks sometimes.

It's all in the set up really. You can't overdo a good thing. Jaws was genuinely frightening. With Jaws, The Revenge all you wanted was for the ending credits to roll by. As to the set ups - well contrived is too easy on them. Just make a situation up and hope you scare the cr*p out of people ^ not.

That is the trouble with disaster/horror flicks. They often really work the first time. Then someone gets the brainwave or is it brain dead and decide to do it again and again and again. It doesn't matter who it is - Friday the 13th, Halloween etc. the original was great and then they wreck it. Film deserves better. Of course on the other side I wasted my time watching it.

review_title: Not the best in the series but.......

review_detailed_main:
I knew that the Jaws sequels are nowhere near as great as the original Jaws movie just by looking at its average IMDb rating, but nevertheless I decide to give them a shot.

Instead of giving it a full review, I will just list out the movie's flaws (in comparison its predecessors):

Firstly, Jaws: The Revenge just like Jaws 3-D does not contain any good performances from any actors, the only performance that may have pleased in the entire movie was Van Peebles' performance even though it was still really bad.














Just like Jaws 3-D, Jaws The Revenge is an embarrassment to the Jaws franchise which was once praised by many for its first film and now loathed for both Jaws 3-D and Jaws The Revenge. Honestly, I am saddened at the fact that a franchise can go from critical acclaim to being unanimously loathed by critics. It is also a shame that the franchise had to end on a bad note.

Quite possibly the worst movie ever.

Who thought this was a good idea???

review_title: The direction is scarier than the shark.
review_detailed_main: Oh Dear whats this all about!!! Alright own up, which studio executive didnt read the script properly and accidentally gave the green light to a movie about a shark that follows individual people around the world intent on revenge. Please take my advice and avoid this film, if you don't believe me just look at the title "Jaws: The Revenge" Oh, what genius, what an original and refreshing title. NOT. If you insist on watching terrible movies watch "Jaws 3D" at least that has some comic merit!

review_title: Recommended only for die hard fans of the "Jaws" series. Or for masochists.
review_detailed_main:
I wonder if Mr. Michael Caine is ashamed of this piece of crap. I have to admit it, when it first came out, I kind of liked it mainly because it featured flashbacks and references to previous "Jaws" movies. Also, I liked Mario Van Peeble's character; I always rooted for Uncle Jake. Also, it was the 80's and "Jaws" needed a final sequel.

Sadly, this movie is terrible in every aspect. The plot is beyond bad although it has a decent opening sequence. This scene is underrated in my opinion, but then the movie terribly falls and becomes a mess.

The body count is minimal taking in account that these kind of movies need many death scenes. The gore, F/X are very cheap and don't have nothing to do with the original "Jaws".

The movie is a disappointment and I can understand why it's on the Bottom 100 on IMDb. What else to say? I would only recommend this movie for die hard fans of the "Jaws" series. If you are not a fan, stay away from this horrible sequel.

What the hell is this crap? What were the people at Universal thinking? Were they really that desperate for a film that they financed something just because it has the name Jaws in it? Ohhh please. So let's get this right, this shark has a personal vendetta against the Brody's now? Why? Did they do anything to this particular shark? Did they kill it's mommy? And if they did, why is it waiting 12 years to extract revenge on the remaining Brody's? Why didn't it come get revenge right after the first one blew up and the second one fried? I guess it had problems communicating with the dead! Oh but wait, there is more stupidity. Ellen has flashbacks of things that she was never there for. I'm sorry, was there a fourth on the Orca? Did she help Brody fire that rifle? Was she on the grassy knoll?

And, yes ladies and gentleman, there is more. When Sean dies she wants to get away from it all and she decides to go the Carribbean. Hey there's an idea. Let's got to the one place where the shark actually has a chance to be. How about a trip to Northern Ontario? Or even to Wisconsin. How about Russia, Germany, Lichtenstein! Anywhere that doesn't have a salted body of water around. I know if I ever got attacked by a bear in the mountains, the first place I would go to get away from it all would be to the mountains, but a little further south! Cause ya know, bears aren't in the mountains down south! Oh and of course the shark makes it to their place of destination before they do. So as one of the other reviewers in here alluded to, I too am going to travel Air Sharky next time I go somewhere. But you know what? I have a perfect script for the next Jaws and I was hoping that maybe they would be reading this review and they could contact me. The story would be simply that Ellen Brody, Michael ( her son ) Michael Caine and all the execs that made this film should be in the next one. Hell put in Joseph Sargeant as well. After all, he is the one that tried to make a film here. So you put all of them in the film and you make Bruce a real shark and we can just watch all of them get eaten, for real. I'm serious too. That would have more of a plot and a story ( a plausible one that is ) than this piece of !@##*. You can call me at 1-976-STUPID-MOVIE.

It's kind of strange, Jaws is my favourite movie of all time. I also think it is the best made film ever. Jaws 4 has got to be the worst film ever made. What a pity. What a piece of #@^*!.

"Jaws: The Revenge" is the fourth movie of Jaws and this one is the worst movie of all. The plot is about the same with the previous but in this movie we have a shark which attacks the boat of Michael Brody and Jake a friend of Michael.

I did not like this movie because it's a movie that none have to watch it. This movie is an insult for the first and best movie "Jaws". I also did not like the interpretation of Mario Van Peebles who played as Jake and Lance Guest who played as Michael Brody. I believe that direction and plot were really horrible and Joseph Sargent did not do his best at this movie.

Finally I have to tell you that you really do not have to watch this movie, it's a not worth seeing movie.

"JAWS: THE REVENGE" is the greatest shark film that everyone hates. Do you know why?

For the same reason that people scoff at Sylvester Stallone's acting: people don't think for themselves, parrot back the loudest opinion they've picked up from the person who thinks for them, and cannot truly see.

The people are dummies.

"Even the people who made it didn't like it!" The monkeys laugh before they reach into their pants for a lump of their most original produce to throw at a wall.

I have never seen so much delusional hatred and mockery for what is basically an average and perfectly serviceable film.

The amount of cringe that goes into this manner of hatred for a film is off the scale. It's wannabe film buffs with no experience of truly bad films, sitting around with their clique, laughing ironically at naff all. "B-b-but it's just terrible!" They snort.

Grow up.

review_title: I love the whole Jaws Franchise!!! I Grew up on These & Enjoy Each Entry.
review_detailed_main:
The revenge is actually really good!!! Actually it's Awesome!!!

It fits nicely as a companion piece to the very first original CLASSIC.

This film concentrates on it's characters & problems they have with real emotional punch & it's a treat to see care taken for characters in this type of fantasy Horror Thriller B-movie.

Jaws the Revenge is the most Horrific by that i mean it's the most Horror movie of the franchise with the killer shark almost like an evil entity or in similar style of a relentless killing machine like Jason Voorhees or Michael Myers as the shark by now is an icon of Horror & the sense of dread is strong as you really feel for the Brody family & feel connected to them for films in & that's why i love the jaws franchise.

Lorraine Gary is an excellent actress & is iconic & great as Ellen Brody & here in revenge this is her movie her story & she's great,i see similarities to Jamie lee curtis' Laurie Strode character as both are survivors of an unstoppable killing machine & both are strong smart women & both are classic Horror genre characters from classic Horror franchises Halloween & Jaws.

Lance Guest is another good part of this film as he is the best version of the older Michael Brody in the franchise he's way better than Dennis Quaid was in Jaws 3.

Lance gives a solid serious performance & you can feel his sadness & his fear he was in Halloween 2 (1981) too & he's a very 80's lead of that time that era he looks cool as Michael with his beard & to me was always the iconic Michael Brody not Dennis Quaid.

The revenge like the other Jaws films i have a soft spot for as i grew up watching these on video & remember always liking the revenge alot well I've always liked all the Jaws films but of course the Spielberg original is the best without a doubt but the revenge is ridiculously underrated & hated on & yet it's a fun & actually emotional sequel!!!

Michael Cain was great fun as Hoegie the quick talking funny pilot who has some nice scenes especially with Ellen Brody their friendship is sweet & nice.

The other characters are fine in their roles like the lovable Mario van peebles, he's fun & very Jamaican lol but a nice guy character. & Lance Guest was good as Michael brody, so in all a good little cast but my main complaint would be the shark itself looks too clean & fake at times it's teeth are bright white & look silly at times but at the same time the Shark still looks terrifying!!!

In my opinion Jaws the revenge is a good film in the franchise but i also have nostalgic for it.

Hey i grew up with this franchise so o can't help but enjoy these movies.

The excellent performance from Lorraine Gary is worth watching this movie for alone but it's also a very good underrated Shark Thriller.

Forget boring critics just enjoy a good Horror Thriller with alot of heart & emotion. Very underrated.

review_title: Terrible end to the Jaws movies.
review_detailed_main: This movie is ridiculous and should not be associated with Peter Benchley's Jaws. The acting was appalling but perhaps the result of bad directing? Even the lovable Michael Caine should be ashamed of his performance. On a technical note; some of the greeen-screening was bad. On saying that, it did have an element of fun and some moments of high tension. Worthy of a watch but don't expect anything great.

review_title: An insult to the legacy of JAWS!!!
By far the worst of the series!
review_detailed_main: The film begins in the town of Amity (where the first 2 movies were set) and focuses on Ellen and Sean Brody (also from the other films in the series). Why this family is still living right on the water after 3 previous life-threatening encounters with great white sharks is beyond me. After Sean is killed by another shark, Ellen decides to head down to the Bahamas with her other son Michael (from the first 3 films). According to Michael, there has never been a great white shark down there, because it is too warm for them. Things get ridiculous when the shark follows them to the Bahamas to seek revenge. The movie has some good points; the cast was decent, the effects were alright, and really might not have been that bad of a movie...However, the idea of humanizing a shark is simply absurd.

Jaws: The Revenge (1987) is a horror thriller film directed by Joseph Sargent, the film was released summer in 1987, and is the last series of Jaws movie franchise. Over the years, Michael and Sean no longer work at Sea World. Michael now has a new life, and Sean lives with his mother after the death of his father (Martin Brody) who suffered a heart attack, but on Christmas Eve, Tragedy again Occurred. Sean who works as a cop succeeds his father. Killed by 28 white sharks, it turns out the shark is hunting the Brody family. The shark wants revenge! ... Will the Brody Family be able to defeat the shark ???? Jaws: The Revenge I watched his movie a few minutes ago via DVD media. This 89-minute movie feels so boring, at the beginning of a movie that is so tragic, but after its just silliness .. Sharks take revenge ??? Ohh no longer .. The effect of white sharks in this film is so stiff and bad .. Unlike in his first film White shark effect in the movie Jaws (1975) is very realistic, and not like a robot .....

review_title: Just when you thought it was safe to go back into the theater.

review_detailed_main: This was so bad, it was almost unwatchable. It suffers from bad acting, bad dialogue, bad accents, bad effects and sloppy directing. The characters are annoying and the shark attack scenes are laughable. The shark attacks are stocky without any suspense whatsoever, and the shark itself looks like a blow-up doll! The actors stand around like dummies because they don't know what to do. It is just so illogical and unconvincing. The climax is absolutely terrible!! I'd love to know what Steven Spielberg thought of this mess...

I love this movie it is very great but I rather watch second and first because Brody needs to be in all of them and he died in this movie so it doesn't really seem like it's not that good but I like it so it's better than Jaws three recommend watching.
Unfair critics , they want to revenge the movies for earning more than a billion dollars ? they earned it . no movie was like the first , and its pretty bad and not realistic but its an OK movie

review_title: The Freddy's dead of the jaws franchise
review_detailed_main: This film is not jaws. Yes it has the music but it is not jaws. The shark sounds most of the film out of the water. It roars and the sound used is a looney toons roar. Just watch the first or second one again. Its not even so bad its good Its just bad.

review_title: a bad flick that completes the jaws tale
Jaws has Finally lost its bite....
review_detailed_main:
Miserable, neurotic adults, brattish, obnoxious children and a dead shark. I know that the shark was never actually alive but in this utterly lame excuse at merchandising, it has rigor mortis, it's so damned stiff!

The people trying to track down this museum piece of floating junk in the Bahamas are shouty, loud and very irritating. Then there's the emotional slush of family get together's as they reminisce and mope.

Even the ever watchable Michael Caine is unbelievable - that he's in such ropey nonsense. He's hardly a bundle of joy, either. Somehow, even the tropical paradise scenery gets tainted in misery.

Watching this on a commercial TV station had, for the about the first time, its upside - yes, the commercials!
This one is even worse than 3-d you don't even watch this one because your eyes are already tortured by 3-d don't watch this please.

The quality of Jaws movies go down throughout the series. This film is let down by some mediocre writing and direction. The dialogue is stiff and forced, characters over explain plot that happened in the previous movies to give first time watchers of the series a heads up and the rest of use a reminder. There is over use of flashbacks and also of memorable moment from the other movies. But, these criticisms are also a plus for the movie. It mines it's heritage and uses the classic moments from past films to create a story rich in callbacks. Although they are often unwittingly comical, they give fans of the films, something to love. Don't go into this movie too seriously and you won't be too disappointed. But if you think this film will reignite the quality of the franchise, your going to be disappointed.

its because of shows like this that people are thinking of sharks as man eating killing machines. they are not. sharks are beautiful creatures. i have dedicated my life to study animals. and i can promise sharks are not like this movie makes them out to be. if this is what people are going to think of sharks or any other animal then they should burn in hell. sharks help keep the fish population down. they breed slowly. they are not as dangerous as crocodiles. people should not take sharks for granted. think about it. any way, when they taste human flesh they spit it out. surfers look like seals from down below. people would make that mistake too. think about it.

review_title: I've seen the same film with two different endings, Very Weird!
review_detailed_main: The first time I saw the film the chap with the dreadlocks (not sure of his name) survived and they killed the shark with an electro magnetic machine. I saw it again the cap with the dreadlocks dies and they blow it up with something completley different to what they did in the other film. Both films were identicle up until the last five/ten minutes weird!

can someone please explain to me how the hell it is that michael caine goes about picking film roles? i'm serious, the overwhelming lack of logic or reason to his actions mystifies me. on the one hand, we have jaws 4, or the other, alfie, cider house rules, blame it on rio (personal reasons). i cannot decide if it is a matter of his being a money grubbing fool lacking in any concept of the what no means...or if he's just really clueless. if he was really clueless, wouldn't he also have to have surrounded himself with a bevy of equally confused morons? surely one of them would have spoken up when he was signing on to do a film about a great white that travels the world to avenge the death of his parents. (well, when you put it like that, maybe it is justifiable?)

With no expectations and expecting this sequel to be bad, it is quite as expected. After watching Jaws 3 and noticing how bad it was in comparison to the previous Jaws film. Jaws: The Revenge is quite worse.

Here the location is set in the Bahamas and features more unlikeable and irritating characters. Giving the wife the lead was a bad decision as her character is far more annoying than the original two films. She came across as too whiny and nagging. Michael Caine comes off across as obnoxious as well and the son Michael Isn't interesting either.

The main lowlights include the climax with the shark roaring than exploding for little to no reason. Easily the worst looking and low budget shark of the series. Also very little shark kills in this film (only 2- the lowest deaths of the franchise).

Featuring virtually no suspense and thrills, this film is just boring to get through. We also wonder as to how Jake survived in the end after being brutally attacked by the shark and taken underwater for a long period of time. Overall this film was not needed and is as terrible as the low ratings suggest.

No pun intended - actually was it the grandpa? I have to admit, this was so forgettable, that I didn't really listen ... I also did not get the difference in the alternate ending ... ok so someone survives who died I reckon? Also do I care? I don't think so - sorry.

That said, this also has some really interesting actors in it. Maybe Mario van Peebles is not top tier for some, but he and his father (a is there a theme her I missed?) changed the landscape of (black) cinema ... anyway the movie has nothing to do with it. Some might even feel this goes the different direction - as good as Mario is, his I reckon Jamaican character is annoying ... and that is putting it mildly.

Anyway, the shark looks good and I imagine if you cut it a lot of slack and accept the "connection" to the first movie (and the major character) ... I guess one can enjoy it ... still carrying it the Jaws name .... the anticipation is way too high a burden ...

review_title: If I could go back in time I would erase this rotten bucket of chum of a movie from history
One of the Worst Sequels of All Time
review_detailed_main: This is the film that ended the Jaws franchise. The first Jaws film never needed a sequel, yet 3 sequels were made with a spectrum of quality ranging from decent to awful. Jaws: The Revenge is at the bottom of that spectrum. This film is depressing, cheap and poorly made. The plot is ridiculous and the characters are all forgettable, aside from the ones that are featured in the first film. This film is soulless and has no purpose for existing. The tone of the film is miserable and is a terrible way to send off the Brody family. This is just a very cheap and forgettable sequel that has no right to exist.

review_title: This Film Should Have Been Shark Bait!!!
Are you in hell or just watching Jaws: The Revenge?
What did you expect? The clue was in the title!

review_detailed_main: Well for one, I did not think Jaws 4 was that bad. I saw it when it was released in theaters, and even though I was young, I did understand a few things. But I also did not understand a few things. Such as the flashbacks to places not witnessed by Ellen. I also had questions on the intelligence and mobility of the shark. But that aside, I felt this movie was not that bad. It had quirky dialogue, fun characters and funny situations. If you can locate it, I recommend seeing the alternate version with Jake surviving (although why the shark and boat explode in this ending is beyond me). Anyway, give a view for fun.

review_title: So bad it's almost good *SPOILER ALERT*

review_detailed_main:
When it comes to Jaws 4: The Revenge, much is said of the bad acting, bad special effects, bad story (the Brodie's being stalked by a shark seeking revenge when Brodie killed that shark twice already??)...but little is said of how there is nothing to this story. There are so many dialog scenes that go on for far too long with no one really saying anything that pad this story out. People whittering on about dinner, Christmas, life anecdotes, etc. With none moving the story forward. I doubt there is forty minutes of actual story here, the rest is mumblecore. How did this thing ever get off the ground.

End.

This movie is an absolute waste of Humanity!

I cant understand why Michael Cain (,a wonderful actor) would agree to do such a piece of crap. The ending, if anyone could actually last that long, was almost as if they ran out of time and/or budget and had to end it on a whim; with no idea, plot, conclusion and/or proper closure... just to end the project and let everyone go home. Im wondering if this was one of those situations.

On a separate note, I really don't understand why there is a ten line minimum on these reviews. Im even trying to "pad" it right now, because the average "writer" (non professional) simply does not require ten lines to get their point across (just my opinion). I'd like IMDb to reconsider this "rule".

review_title: Listen it's bad but it's entertainingly bad
review_detailed_main: Look I agree with the general public (by a little) that this is a pretty bad movie, BUT and this is a HUGE BUT.....i was entertained? Look the first jaws is my all time favorite movie ever since I was a child, jaws 2 is a decent sequel but it's just not the first, JAWS 3 is legit one the worst film's I've ever seen, even as a kid I thought it was terrible, and this one is just so bad it's good. Like yes the story is stupid and the acting is hilariously bad but that's what made this movie for me, the entire time I was just laughing at how ridiculous this film is. Yes it's a bad movie, it's story is truly garbage but again for the millionth time, this is a sharknado situation where the movie is so bad it's entertaining while I watched jaws 3 it bored the hell out of me, it's the first time I watched a movie and was dreading for it to be over. Now if you haven't seen this movie and your looking for a story like In the original jaws, this film will make you lose your mind, BUT if your a sucker for stupid shark movies, this is one of my guilty pleasures.

review_username: Jenz at Bullets n Babes DVDs
review_title: Really lost the vision of the first...
review_detailed_main: Nothing in this film was new. It was a rapid case of been there done that that held no interest. Oh how we hope for a decent Shark Thriller to honour "Jaws".

About halfway through this movie my allegiance was entirely for the shark and still is. That the shark would find within itself the resources necessary to reduce the remainder of the Brody Clan to shark poop deposited on the floor of the ocean. This was on my mind throughout most of this movie.

Sarcasm aside, this movie was ridiculous. Cinematic trash.

Don't waste your time. Go do something else, even if it's wrong.

Do you have a collectors set of old Laverne & Shirley reruns? Watch those instead. Problem solved ! Or you could take up stamp collecting. Have you considered taking up basket weaving?

I digress.

review_title: SERIOUSLY... Get Out Of The Water!!!
Jaws: The Revenge on 4k ultra hd

The action shark scenes I thought were entertaining. I would say the 2nd movie of the franchise was the worst and this and the 3rd (in 3d) are actually worth watching.

Jaws the Revenge is crap, it has no story line, no plot, no good characters, and I wish that the little girl Thea had got eaten, sadly she did not. Only 2 people were killed, when the whole cast should have been eaten alive. I hated this so much I felt like crying, after spending all that money on this useless piece of rubbish, also it does come in handy on my un even chair.
