A 1 and a half out of 10

This is truly one of the worst films I've ever seen. I liked the first Jaws pretty well, thought the second one was OK but had a hunch that the second one should have been the last. Boy was I right! I never thought I'd rate a film with one of my favorite actors, Michael Caine, in it so low, but it finally happened. Roy Scheider had sense enough to sit this one out. Michael Caine should have as well. Total waste of time and celluloid.

review_title: Unbelievable and not in a good way.
review_detailed_main: All reviews for this film can be summed up through a single quote from Michael Caine who starred in the film: " I have never seen it, but by all accounts it is terrible. However, I have seen the house that it built, and it is terrific!"

review_title: The worst Movie I have EVER Seen
review_detailed_main: Forget about that the shark is tracking certain individuals ...maybe...just maybe...that could skate by as a Hollywood dramatic premise...BUT ...the shark somehow finds out she is going to the Caribbean and beats her there ...the shark actually arrives before Mrs. Brody...Amazing....giving note that the fastest way to the Caribbean is by shark not plane....I'll bet booking a fare is pretty cheap.
I lasted 15 minutes. Threw the DVD in the bin. Absolutely awful movie. Zero plot, zero effects, terrible story and acting. I'm amazed Michael Caine agreed to participate in this disastrous movie.

review_title: More boring than The Star Wars Holiday Special
review_detailed_main: I had heard this was a terrible film, so watched it to see if it was so-bad-it's-good. It isn't, the reason for its low rating is simple: it is incredibly boring. There's a very brief moment of action early on, then nothing for about an hour. This would be fine if the writing was strong enough to support a dialogue-driven film, however all the lines are dull and uninteresting. Even when the shark attacks, it can feel boring due to over-use of slow motion. This is why I'm giving it a 3, because I reserve the one and two star reviews for films so poorly constructed that they become fun to watch. This will simply make you wait for it to end.

This movie was literally so bad that it killed Judi Barsi the next year. The mother in it is horrible. Michael Cain might as well just give up on acting after doing this crappy film. The shark somehow moved backwards and forwards. Even up and down. Lance Guest should have stuck with flying spaceships and talking to turd people. This movie killed the careers of these poor actors. A shark that has revenge on a family in Massachusetts somehow follows them down the coast against the current and suddenly can survive in warm tropical temperatures. I would tell people to watch this movie mainly for the laughs and nothing else. Beware of the banana scene though. The underwater scenes are somewhat decent though. With the eel jumping out and with the conk shells. Maybe Michael Brody was tagging the shells to see what their migration periods were like. At some points the shark looks as big as a house and at others as small as a door frame. I give this a 1 and if I could, a 0.5. The only redeeming parts were the underwater shots. So get some popcorn and get ready for a wildly stupid film.

review_title: Spoilers alert? You must be joking...

review_detailed_main:
You can say whatever you want about this movie (and most people have said a lot!), but there is no finer line in any film than when Jake manages to tag the shark and the crew member screams "YES JAKE, YOU GOT HIM MAAAN" in the greatest West Indian accent ever to grace the big screen!

Admittedly the rest of the film really is an appalling mess of bad acting, terrible effects, reused footage and pretty much every single bad thing that can cause a movie to be terrible. It's one of those things; if you like Jaws films you'll like this regardless. If you don't, this could easily be the worst film you'll ever see!

Where to start? Geez! How about the fact that the shark is supposedly seeking revenge against the living family of the man (Roy Schieder) who killed it all those years ago? If you think this sounds implausible, you're in for one hell of a treat, because this sorry third sequel makes one yearn for the groundbreaking original (heck, I was scrambling for Jaws 2!). At one point in the movie the heroine is stricken with flashbacks to events that occurred in the original (curiously, she was not present for these events, and therefore could not be remembering them, but the filmmakers think we're stupid I guess.)When we see these flashbacks, we feel not nostalgia but pity, because the brilliant piece of work that was the original JAWS is being desecrated by even appearing in this vile excuse for a movie.

review_title: They should have left it with the 3rd
Just when you thought it was safe to go back to the cinema...
review_detailed_main: After Jaws 3D I thought they'd gotten as low as they could get, and then they made this movie... It turns out I was wrong, it could get worse. Much worse. Jaws was a great movie, Jaws 2 was viewable, Jaws 3 was plain awful, but this... This goes right off the scale, way below the lowest point. The only movie in this series where you find yourself actually hoping the shark would win.

This is what we want! This is what the punters have all paid to see: Michael Caine battling a shark with a personal vendetta.

Disappointingly, though, Jaws: The Revenge's reputation as a superturkey of the highest calibre is a little overblown. Oh, sure, it is pretty bad, but it doesn't qualify for the premier league of celluloid waste that counts among its number Batman & Robin, Speed 2 and The Avengers.

None of the Jaws sequels were really dire, of course, merely so-so and average. The first possessed possibly the most famous tagline in movie history, though was strangely unengrossing. The second suffered from the obvious demands of its 3-D format, though even that probably isn't as bad as you might remember.

While obviously not containing the worth of the original mainstream classic, the sequels were popular enough to reach film No.4, which surprisingly features Michael Caine in only a relatively minor role. That said, an unusually tubby Caine does give sufficient enthusiasm to what you can tell he knows are third-rate lines. However, despite cod Jamaican accents, the general personal workings of the film are well in order, if not terribly exciting. The word of mouth that the shark is after revenge turns out to be a misnomer. The only person in the film who believes this to be the case is the traumatised Ellen Brody. Okay, there is one point where she seems to be psychic, but generally this is never as silly as it is purported to be. The frequency of the shark's attacks may seem farfetched, but never more than in any of the other films. In conclusion, the subtitle for the film seems to be based on Brody's desire for vengeance, rather than that of the "overgrown goldfish". The tagline - This time it's personal - has been similarly misunderstood.

But the real sticking point comes with the shark itself. Whereas the others had used a dummy shark only sparingly, opting in the main for genuine shots of such a creature, here the action seems to be wholly taken over with an animatronic puppet. None of the movies in the series were able to do this successfully. The original and Jaws 3-D were acceptable if you squinted and applied a kind eye, whereas the second produced the odd wry smile. Here though, the dummy used looks shabby and plasticcy, several shots appearing to reveal zippers and wiring on the creature's casing. Let's be honest  even Stevie Wonder wouldn't be convinced that this was a real shark. It looks ridiculous, and every time it appears, which is often, the audience cannot help but roar their hysterical disbelief.

Some hilarious goofs - including a waterlogged Caine emerging from the ocean with dry clothes, and a roaring shark - push the laughter factor even higher. Underdeveloped denouement drags this half-hearted film towards the end credits, a shambling mess with a joke as its major star, the actors only underwritten support. Yet, sadly, it's still not enough to make this a enjoyably bad film. Jaws: The Revenge suffers the ultimate indignity of merely being lacklustre. 4/10.

review_title: Jaws 3D looks like an inspired work of art in comparison
review_detailed_main:
Joe Sargent is a more than capable director with several Emmy's under his belt and Michael Caine is a fine actor who had the misfortune of working on a film that is not only the worst of his career but which also prevented him from receiving his Oscar in person because of location shooting for this movie.

"Jaws: The Revenge" is almost too easy to pick on. Sure, the island scenery is gorgeous to look at and there are plenty of pretty girls but, yikes, that first reveal of the shark is the final blow to any credibility that this movie was hoping to have.

The alternate TV version, in an attempt to make some sense of what the viewer is about to see, adds a needless voice over that only serves to make the entire premise of the movie even more absurd.

This was near the top of my bad movie list (just before MANOS: THE HANDS OF FATE) but both have been displaced by Timothy Hines' THE WAR OF THE WORLDS. No easy feat, to be sure.

For me to rate something 1/10 is highly unusual. The way I see it, 1/10 is as bad as it gets. And this movie is just that! I honestly don't think I have ever seen anything worse than this. I had the misfortune of watching this movie during a marathon. I decided to watch all the Jaws movies in one sitting because the original masterpiece by Spielberg made me curious.. I regret actually going through with it. Now I can't go back.. This disaster of a movie will forever be stuck in my head.. It will probably haunt my soul even after my death..

Whoever made this: I hope you sleep well at night. I truly do...

Even though a lot of critics thought this should never have been made well that's rubbish & continues the story of the Brodie family and the shark and the story to be honest was very well done & having Micheal Caine in it was genius. A real worth while watch

review_title: This film can be funny if treated as a comedy

review_detailed_main:
JAWS THE REVENGE may be the most laughable excuse for a movie I have ever seen. In this (hopefully) final entry, Ellen Brody visits her son Mike, now married with a young daughter, in the Bahamas. But little does she know that the shark that killed her other son has followed her and starts attacking people, including her grand-daughter. JAWS 3-D was bad enough, but at least that one had cool effects. There is nothing good about this one. At all. The effects are so cheap that they make SUPERMAN IV look like TITANIC, and the thrill is gone. Very, very laughable.

0 out of 5

What makes this film such an outlandish waste of reel? The real question is, what doesn't? The only good part of this movie (and I mean ONLY) is Michael Caine. I don't fault him for being a part of it, because an actor who doesn't act is, well, nothing. Plus, by his own admission, it was certainly an effective way to remind moviegoers of the dozens of excellent pictures on which he has worked. He was paid for his performance, and given his remarkable talent, he deserved it. But his natural screen presence was so utterly out of place in this vomit-inducing train wreck. Caine aside, the acting is horse manure, and the already inept cast members are not helped by a disgraceful excuse for a screenplay. A shark that singles out the relatives of the man who killed a couple of other sharks once? Where does this nonsense come from? Finally, the mud on the worm cake is Joseph Sargent's utterly by-the-numbers direction. Granted, he had so very little to work with, but he still failed, as did this movie.

review_title: The end of the line for Mr. Whitey
review_detailed_main:
Mercifully, the increasingly ludicrous JAWS series came to an end with this mediocre third sequel to the 1975 suspense masterpiece. Lorraine Gary returns as Ellen Brody, convinced now, after her youngest son, the Amity town sheriff, is killed in Amity Harbor while investigating a shipwreck, that the shark is now after her entire family as "revenege"(??). She tries to unwind in the Bahamas with her oldest son Mike (Lance Guest) and a local pilot (Michael Caine). But the shark won't let her, and it comes down to a climax that, while spectacular, is also totally ludicrous, and not helped by the device of Gary having flashbacks to events in the original film she was never even a witness to.

The only thing that saves JAWS 4 from total disaster is the relatively good direction of Joseph Sargent (COLOSSUS: THE FORBIN PROJECT) and Michael Small's score, which integrates John Williams' original theme. Otherwise, this revenge is a dish either best eaten cold or not eaten at all.

review_title: I thought nothing could be more worse then Jaws 3-D...
review_detailed_main:
It was in the start of the Swedish summer (that includes rain) and Swedish Chanel 3 showed Jaws:The Revenge in the late evening. I had just seen Jaws 2 and 3-D so I thought I'll watch number 4 to expand my "have seen" movie list. Oh Boy! Could I have used the time much better?? Oh Yes I could have!!

This movie was even more worse then Jaws 3-D (and thats B-A-D!). I wonder if Michael Caine had a money problem in those days because what else made him be a part of this piece of crap?

Although the beginning of the film is a little terrifying it doesn't help that the shark is unbelievable fake and the story unbelievable dumb and dumberer. The big nasty (fake) Jaws is probably a relative to the earlier sharks in Jaws 1,2 and 3 and he want's revenge on the Brody family...incredible silly!

But the dumbest in the movie is when the shark is supposed to have been swimming from the little cold harbor village of Amity to the warm seas of the Bahamas...

I did my duty 1/10.

review_title: Go on, have a good laugh watching this.
This movie may have bad shark effects, but the actors save the movie.
You Already Know This Movie Sucks!
review_detailed_main: The Movie, For Me, Isn't Fun To Watch. The First Jaws Is Probably In The Top 10 Movies Of All Time, & Jaws 2 Is a Great Sequel, & Jaws 3-D Is a Guilty Pleasure Of Mine, The Only Good Thing About This Is: 1: The Poster, 2: The Title, And 3: John Williams Score, And That's It! This Movie's Just a Huge, Big, Fat, Middle Finger To JAWS 1, 2, & 3-D, Steven Spielberg, And Sharks! The Shark Roars, And For The Most Part Does Almost NOTHING! I Hatted The Main Character, Nothing Against The Actors But They Did Not Try To Save This Dumpster. It Just Ignores The 3rd Movie All Together & Pretenders That It's The 3rd Jaws (Which It's NOT!!). At Leat Jaws 3-D Was Trying. But This Is Just a Crash-Grabbing Piece Of S***! Also Did I Mention That The Shark Roars Like a Loin?! I Hate This Movie SO MUCH!!

This is the third and final sequel of the original Jaws, where Chief Brody's widow, Ellen, decides that she has had enough of Amity and heads off to the Caribbean to join her son Michael, daughter-in-law Carla and granddaughter Thea. However, the Great-White Shark shows up again, taking younger son Sean's life and causing uneasiness to Ellen. Therefore, she wages a personal revenge mission against the shark that has caused her and her family so much grief.

The plot sounds pretty interesting but, to sum it all up in a few words, this movie is pretty boring. It is basically just mediocre drama with sub-par acting, showing the characters preaching endlessly about their livelihoods and plans on what to do with the shark, which appears in a few scenes only. There is really not much shark action or suspense until the climax of the film.

Overall, it's the worst off of the Jaws movies and one you can definitely stay out of the water.

Grade D--

Look I know they were probably running out of ideas cause they didn't really intend to make a Jaws 3 or 4 or even a 2 for that matter, but they didn't even try!!!! OK first off how and why is Jake still alive at the end of the movie even though he just got attacked by a shark?!? Why are Hoagies clothes still dry after he's been in the water?!? Why is Jaws roaring like a lion have sharks change since the last time we've seen them?!?!

review_title: I really haven't seen anything like this before
review_detailed_main:
my rating: 1/10

Just for the record, I must say that I didn't enjoy the original Steven Spielberg's Jaws, either. Of course it is a mark of a great director with huge talents, but it really didn't work out for me. I gave the original Jaws a rating 6/10, so it wasn't still that bad --- compared to its sequels. If I can remember correctly, this is the fourth and the most futile chapter in the series and yes, this is one of the most lamest movies I have ever seen. The plot is just ridiculous and the acting and the special effects were like from a movie made in 1920's. Perhaps not, but this movie is a disgrace for the movie Jaws --- even when I didn't like it, I can't deny the fact that it is a classic --- and one of the most lamest movies I've seen.. hey, did I already mention that? A shark having personal problems with the leading character? Sounds so exciting!

review_title: RIP .. once was a great film
review_detailed_main:
With so many talented people associated and the mere passage of time since the original, you'd think it would be possible if not to surpass the original in quality, to at least manage to build a more realistic, ergonomic, technologically advanced shark. Not so apparently when you see what this shark does to a banana boat looking more rubbery than a latex muppet and at a reported forty feet (!) giving way to the sheer absurd.

Same old story rehashed with Lance Guest now assuming the lead role (taking up where Dennis Quaid left off in 3D), his long suffering mother (played by the original Lorraine Gary, though one wonders why she waited nine years to return for this abomination; perhaps it was the Caribbean location) hell-bent on taking revenge on the most recent predator to rip a limb off her diminishing family tree. And then there's Michael Caine playing a care-free helicopter pilot named "Hoagie". It's a toss-up between this turkey, "The Swarm", "Beyond the Poseidon Adventure" or "Blame it on Rio" as to which is his all time worst effort. Caine dances in this film while romancing Gary, so it's a tight contest.

Not an ounce of suspense or even mild shock is created by the director of "The Taking of Pelham 123", Joseph Sargent apparently absent from the director's chair for most of what ended up on the screen. Good to see younger and elder Van Peebles together, even if they have to share the ignominy of it being in this film. There's little to recommend, needless to say if you're a fan of the franchise, then you absolutely must see this to fully appreciate just how good the others are by comparison.

After seeing Jaws 3-D I thought a Jaws-movie can't be worse.

Apparently, it can. The story of this fourth 'Jaws' is full of big holes, but the action sequences... Those would rather belong to a Mel Brooks-parody! An example: the shark gets out of the water, rests on its tail for a few seconds, seems to 'fall' on a swimmer and devours it afterwards. Scary, isn't it?

review_title: Promises much, but ultimately delivers very little.
Not as bad as people make out.
It's Been 12 Long Years Since The First Encounter, And This Shark Still Holds A Grudge.

review_detailed_main:
It always makes me sad when someone makes a great film, and then has too many sequels that ruin the first one. Steven Spielberg (director of Jaws, Jurassic Park. Writer of Poltergeist) has had that happen in those three films I mentioned above. I was amazed that a sequel could be any worse than the stupid and gimmicky Jaws 3, but it was. When this first starts, it seems like it might be an okay film, with interesting camera angles and direction, but it gets worse. The protagonist of this film is Brodie's wife, and she gets really annoying. This movie also houses perhaps the dumbest scene in any movie I have ever seen where the shark comes out of the water and roars. Later we hear the roar in the end credits theme song. I'm almost hoping for a Jaws 5 to redeem this piece of ...., but I'm sure it would also be bad, so let's just pretend like the last three Jaws movies didn't happen.

My rating: 1/2 out of ****. rated PG-13 for violence.

review_title: Dear lord, I can't believe I watched it all!!
Please stop making Jaws sequels forever!!!
review_detailed_main:
Chief Brody's widow believes that her family is deliberately being targeted by another shark in search of revenge.

This is what is says on the label.. How can this movie be any good??

If you have seen the 3rd movie you are already aware that Jaws is going downhill in each new episode they make..

I was not even aware there was a movie called Jaws 3 because after I watched the Jaws 2 I already had understood this thing will not be a Terminator or Alien or even Rambo...And today I found out that the torture was not enough and they decided to make Jaws the Revenge!!!!

Worse than the Jaws 3rd, this movie gets a 1 or 2 rating from me..

Wow just wow. SMH.

Poor wouldn't begin to describe it. The acting is terrible, the fake shark ridiculously fake, and there is no suspense whatsoever. I did give it one star since there are some laugh out loud moments due to the poor quality of the whole movie. Sometimes it looked like the shark was suffering from gingivitis, when it was attacking boats and I felt bad for it. Had to fast forward through some scenes that were too long. Other scenes that could have made the movie watchable were way too short leaving the viewer to fill in the gaps.

review_title: Just When You Thought it Was Safe to Watch Another Jaws Movie...
Not that bad. It's shot beautifully at some points as well.
review_detailed_main: The fact that they started with a shark attack at night is a big plus. The film has bad dialogue and bad shots of sharks. It's a bit bloody though....IMDB probably put this at the bottom list because they compared it to part 1. IMDB probably made it personal. Lol

review_title: If mediocrity were flab, this bloated, blubbery goldfish would be a whale.
review_detailed_main:
In this fourth (although the studio promoted it as being the third film in the "trilogy") and presumably final entry in this once proud series, Bruce the shark has undergone a transformation from great white shark, to a bloated, blubbery goldfish flushed down the toilet bowl years earlier, only to end up as this insultingly stupid, poorly written, blandly directed waste of film, good only for unintentional laughs, and a lot of them.

Christmastime setting is the only novelty here, as Ellen Brody, mourning the death of her husband from parts I and II, loses one of her sons in another shark attack. Her other son convinces her to go to the Bahamas with him and his family, to take her mind off everything. That just makes her go even more crazy, and insist the shark has targeted her family as part of some ridiculous voodoo curse.

Yes, you read that correctly: a voodoo curse is the reason why her family has been beset by shark attacks.

Voodoo curses, revenge, drug smuggling, the return of a little-used supporting character having flashbacks to events that she was not present for, and a large plastic shark (which roars!) are all thrown into this mix, then Puréed in a blender, and thrown onto the screen, in one giant *splat*

This is the only Jaws film not written by Carl Gottlieb and Howard Sackler, whether that's good or bad is open to debate.

There is a difference between fictional story writing, and insultingly stupid story writing. The makers of this thing thought that the audiences would accept, with perhaps only a minor suspension of disbelief, any story at all, no matter how ridiculous or implausible it is, as long as it has the "Jaws" name attached to it, and as long as someone from the original cast returned. It expects you to not only suspend your disbelief, but also requires you to be dimmer than a one- star restaurant, and pretend to not notice the footage from part I being reused at the ludicrous climax, and not question how characters miraculously return to life after being devoured by the shark. And repeatedly ignore the very obviously visible tracks the shark is "swimming" on. And ignore the support beams used to lift the shark into the air. And ignore an obvious miniature, which explodes for no apparent reason, and does so four times, for the film's quickly reshot alternative ending. And, is that duct tape I see, holding the body of the shark together? Supposedly a twenty million dollars budget for this, and that's the best they could do, duct tape and stock footage?

The Jaws theme is used all throughout the opening credit scene, quickly ruins its effectiveness; it is a dramatic piece, not to be used during something as mundane as the opening credits, seemingly just to remind people they are watching a Jaws film. Michael Caine's potential love interest for Lorraine Gray's character is filler material; it goes absolutely nowhere, and his character could be edited out almost completely and his absence would not even be noticed. But the same could probably be said for Gary's character, also.

Good shock of the boat suddenly being attacked from underneath in the opening shark attack, one of the few memorable shots. The rest of the film is only good for lots of unintentional laughs, which is why I rated it as highly as I did.

If one doesn't include the three or four minutes long opening credits, and the four minutes long closing credits, the film's real run-time drops to about 81/ 82 minutes.

review_title: One of the Worst Films of All Time!
review_detailed_main:
I can suspend my disbelief to allow for a vengeful shark to come after the Brody family. After all, he was killed in two other movies (#3 was a different shark, with different people) by the same guy (Roy Scheider's Chief Brody. He was smart and didn't come back for this one.) But a lot of inconsistencies and idiotic, laughable things occur in Jaws the Revenge. One of the most famous is the scene where the shark stands on its tail in the water and almost leaps onto Mrs. Brody's tiny boat. Apparently she wasn't told of her husband's quote about getting a bigger boat. Her dreams/nightmares provide her with memories of things she couldn't possibly have seen but not that one. Michael Caine brings nothing to the film, except for the novelty of the fact that he couldn't pick up his first Oscar because he was filming this movie! Lucky for him he won a second one (I think they felt sorry that he missed out for this trash film). No suspense, no horror, bad acting, horrible writing. They only green-lighted this based on the concept, you see. They thought 'Gee, we can make money with another Jaws movie. How 'bout if the shark is angry and wants revenge.' That would've been fine...if they had attempted to make a smarter movie.

I've seen a lot of bad movies but this one is among the very worst. It goes on my list with "Godzilla 1985" and "Dracula's Dog" as one of the worst horror films on record.

review_title: The three things that will make you hate yourself for watching this film...
This is not a decent nor spectacular sequel in the Jaws series.
review_detailed_main:
Jaws: The Revenge shouldn't even have been made. At the rate, we're dealing with a mammoth shark that stands on its tail and roars like a lion. Where's the suspense? The shark only eats and kills 2 people throughout a 1 hour and 31 minute film. This "Jaws" is simply the worst. I think this movie should have won more Razzie Awards than it did. One of the most sad things that really bother me is that Lorraine Gary stars in this poor, pitiful excuse for a Jaws movie. She had great influence in the 1st and 2nd Jaws films and decided to just give that all up. Not only that, but, getting Michael Caine into a movie like this. My opinion was that he was in this for the money. He showed absolutely no skill in this movie at all. The acting is atrocious, and I'm still concerned with the "Hey, man!" quote from this embarrassing film. Do yourself a favor and throw out every single "Jaws: The Revenge" DVD in the garbage because it's just so terrible!

4/10

Jaws: The Revenge can be summed up in one word: an insult. That's right, this movie is an insult to the original ground breaking 1975 classic. It is also insulting to the audiences who should feel cheated and insulted at this atrocity of a movie. It should be an insult to the many actors involved in this movie, including but not limited to Michael Caine and Mario Van Peebles. Steven Spielberg, director of the first movie should feel insulted considering the memory of the first movie has been stomped on but then again he has nothing to do with this movie. Peter Benchley, the author of the novel Jaws which the first movie was based on should also be insulted that this marked the death of the Jaws franchise. I should also add that this should be an insult to Universal Studios who was responsible for this, but then again somebody must have thought that this was going to be a good idea and like a cash cow, milk it for all its worth.

Jaws: The Revenge focuses on the now widowed Ellen Brody (Lorraine Gary) and her family is being targeted by a great white shark following the horrific death of her deputy sheriff son Sean (Mitchell Anderson) who was killed while on duty. She becomes further paranoid when she believes a great white has followed her and her family to the Bahamas to target the remaining family members in revenge for the deaths of the sharks in the first two Jaws movies.

The tagline sums up the entire movie: "This time it's personal". Are you serious?! Are audiences REALLY meant to believe a great white shark is going to seek revenge on family members with its own vendetta. I'm very puzzled here. Are audiences meant to get excited about a shark targeting members of the Brody clan after Martin Brody (Roy Schneider) killed the infamous great white shark from Jaws (1975) and Jaws 2 (1978)? This is completely wrong and surely someone must have piped up during the development of the forth movie and said "This is going to be a bad idea" unless they were told to shut up or they decided that this was going to be a good idea. Already this movie was going to have disaster written all over it.

Jaws is a classic, the second movie was worth watching, and the third was an inferior movie which should have ended the Jaws series at number 3 (actually it was Jaws 3-D to capitalise of 3-D movies).

Jaws: The Revenge should be left to sink to the bottom of the ocean.

1/10.

review_title: so bad you have to see it
SHOWS THAT SEQUELS SHOULD NOT BE MADE
A sad end to an incredible movie series
Ok,ok...I'll say it! This movie bites!
big moma shark versus kinda skeleton-like moma Brody
The worst thriller movie ever made
Looking for stupidness... you got it right there!
This movie BITES!!! Ha, Ha you get it. Bites (UGH)
The Revenge of the Worst Film Ever Made

Let's try this again, shall we?
All sequel and no plot make this a dull movie!
I pity those fools who spent $6 to see this at the movie in 1987...
Perhaps the worst film ever made
Roy Scheider Proves He's Smarter Than We Thought
Terrible, Unrealistic, and Just Plain Bad
revenge NOT so sweet in this movie
Michael Caine, what were you thinking???????
Jaws was great, Jaws 2 was allright, Jaws 3-D was fair. But this one, None of the above.
What The Hell Were You Smoking!
